title: jacob rees mogg brexit compromise
story: It would mean extending the transition period from the end of  to December  but with the UK following EU rules and paying an extra £billion into Brussels coffers.It would also mean replacing the Irish backstop with technological solutions while leaving the option open of exiting the EU on World Trade Organisation rules –a free-trade deal has not been struck.The idea was named after housing minister Kit Malthouse, who brought the two sides together in secret. Here, leading Conservative Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg offers his view:THE EU has taken an almost religious approach to Britain’s latest move towards securing a Brexit deal.The compromise put forward by my fellow MP Kit Malthouse has been immediately dismissed and any prospect of further negotiation turned away. The mighty EU has spoken and will not be gainsaid.In negotiating the compromise, both Leavers and Remainers made concessions. This has led to criticism from their supporters, as I found in my weekly radio show on LBC.Callers felt that I had become a “snowflake” in my willingness to see £billion of taxpayers’ money spent without giving us any advantage in future negotiations.The legal basis for the EU demanding money is weak. A House of Lords report came to the conclusion that while there could be a moral obligation, under UK, EU and international law there was no valid or forceful claim.The only motive for paying is to secure a good future deal, rather than to pay a ransom for our freedom.Yet I have come to the conclusion that leaving on March  is at risk and exiting the EU is a prize worth paying for and on which thewill be great.Unfortunately, in spite of the Referendum result, the majority of MPs are reluctant to see the UK part from the EU and at the least want terms that mirror our membership.This may well not be the view of most voters, who seem to welcome the clean break and are not fearful of the scare stories.It is, therefore, crucial to ensure the fears of those who are far from enthusiastic Brexiteers are assuaged. This is where the Malthouse Compromise comes in.By offering money and making the prospect of a No Deal Brexit unlikely, possible moderate former Remainers are willing to avoid Parliamentary tactics that would frustrate our departure.They can accept the replacement of the backstop, which could keep us tied in to the EU’s rules and courts forever, with a routine trade agreement based on existing processes commonly used around the world.This would not hamper the development of a future relationship which would be discussed once we have left. Although in these discussions we would lose the leverage of cash, we would not be squeezed by the backstop.The second stage of the compromise is that the implementation period could be extended by one year. Currently the withdrawal agreement proposes a maximum of two years.In this time we would remain subject to EU laws and what follows, but it makes the prospect of not finalising a future relationship less likely, which gives comfort to those who are determined to avoid No Deal.In my view, an extra  months of vassalage after  years is an unwelcome but not unaffordable price to pay. Critics may ask why Brexiteers want to lessen the chance of a No Deal departure — and the reason is simple.Regardless of the folly of Project Fear, which becomes more preposterous by the day, the Parliamentary arithmetic means we must either lessen the prospect by compromise or it will be done by sharp practice in the House of Commons.This could lead to delay or even no Brexit at all. This would destroy any remaining trust of politicians in our constitutional settlement, it would show reckless contempt for voters, yet the Brexit-denying amendment put forward by Yvette Cooper last week was only defeated by  votes.As with all compromises, Malthouse is not perfect but is enough for each side of the argument in the UK to accept.The question remains, will the EU response be positive  So far, it has not.This has always been at the heart of the debate, and in a way a compelling reason for going. Is the EU a Mafia-style organisation that has to punish countries that do not subscribe to its religion Their response to the Malthouse Compromise and the PM’s request to re-open the text will answer this question. It must be clear to the EU that the current withdrawal agreement will not do.Defeated in the Commons by the largest margin ever achieved in the lower house on Government business, it is simply too one-sided and allows too great a triumph to the EU.If the EU were to insist on its inalterability requiring the punishment of a recalcitrant, freedom-loving nation then it will reveal its true and barbarous colours. It would be evident on its own that we are right to leave.How much better it would bethis were wrong and that in fact the EU is the civilised organisation it claims to be — respecting democracy, the nation state and constitutional procedures. In a few weeks we will know.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: theresa may brexit negotiations poker
story: Last week’s Commons victory over Remainers — a surprise to everyone including the PM herself — has given her a strong hand to play for Britain.The PM has the unexpected authority of Parliament to scrub the hated Northern Ireland backstop. Her squabbling party has called a temporary truce. And nobody, including the EU, wants Jeremy Corbyn to take control.Even Labour MPs are rallying behind her — at a price. And working-class voters have given the Tories a healthy seven-point lead. They might even win a snap election.Played skilfully, this could win a deal that satisfies both Remainers and Leavers.Yet there are fears Mrs May will use it to revive her wretched Chequers plan, which sparked the resignations of Boris Johnson and David Davis, or the botched deal thrown out last month by a -vote margin.She has made a worrying start by apparently binning the No Deal card — the only one that truly scares the EU. Mrs May has no intention of playing this ace — and never had.There are other worrying signs.This showdown with EU hardliners requires fresh thinking and shrewd advice from seasoned players. Crawford Falconer, an ex-World Trade Organisation ambassador, was recruited by the Brexit department for precisely these skills.Indeed, he is the ONLY person in the Government machine who has ever negotiated a trade deal.Yet bafflingly, Mrs May is keeping this star player on the sidelines.Instead, she will fly to Brussels with Whitehall mandarin Olly Robbins, the pro-EU fanatic who plunged Britain into the backstop trap she is now under pressure to escape from.Robbins hates Brexit and has privately warned the PM this is Mission Impossible.Mrs May — herself a Remainer who has never grasped the case for Brexit — will be joined by trusted “deputy PM” David Lidington, a dyed-in-the-wool Brussels worshipper.In such company, even the inclusion in her team of a thundering Brexiteer Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox is only mildly reassuring.Mrs May is notoriously stubborn. She can also be devious.After nearly three years, even her closest political colleagues — who can be counted on one hand with a couple of missing digits — have no idea what her Brexit might look like.Voters are increasingly irritated by this foot-dragging.Why should we remain part of an organisation that wants to punish us by stealing Gibraltar, Northern Ireland and our car industry Nobody who watched the brutal humiliation of poor little Greece will be surprised. This tragic and insolvent nation should never have been admitted to the EU, still less the Eurozone.Only with the assistance of US banking giant Goldman Sachs — “The Vampire Squid” — got them in under the wire. Once inside, they launched a borrowing and spending binge which ended in tears in the  crash.Greece might have flourished as a cheap but lovely tourist economy. Instead, it is now being cruelly tormented by Brussels and lumbered with multi-billion euros debts it can never repay.Greece symbolises all that is wrong with arrogant Brussels — the catastrophic Euro, inflexible economic policies and mass unemployment for under-s.Above all, there is the sneering contempt of unsackable Eurocrats for the million people they rule from subsidised ivory towers.Theresa May is a poor negotiator who never truly believed No Deal is better than a bad deal.Without this implicit threat, Brussels will give little and demand much in . It would be a pleasure to eat my words and watch Mrs May play a blinder.She can use her good luck to land a historic victory. Or she can blink and condemn Britain to colony status, paying billions more into EU coffers while being led by the nose on trade deal promises that never materialise.In which case, forget about that snap election fantasy.The Conservative Party would never be forgiven by the .million voters who voted Brexit — or those who wish they had.SECURITY CHIEFS are dusting off Cold War plans anticipating a Soviet nuclear strike to whisk the Queen to safety in the event of . . .  er . . . a No Deal Brexit.Presumably The Mall will be cleared of traffic and used as a landing strip to fly Her Maj out before revolutionary Remainers string her up for supporting Brexit.The only question is whether she will go quietly.The royals refused to leave London even after Buckingham Palace was bombed during the Second World War.This Project Fear nonsense is even more insane than the idea that thousands will die of fruit shortages.To quote Corporal Jones: “Don’t panic!!”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The public is sick to the back teeth of politicians seemingly unable to carry out the task set for them twice over in a Referendum and a General Election: to take us out of the European Union, with a good deal or a managed clean break.For the first time in months, Parliament last week took a giant step in that direction – and the Prime Minister and the Cabinet should be focussed on delivering the changes to the backstop that the Commons demanded.That should be the only thing on anybodys mind in Westminster.Once we are free of the EU’s shackles, the priority must be to supercharge the British economy, with a new Chancellor and a reinvigorated party setting a course for Britain to become ever more competitive on the global stage.The Party can start on genuine reform of the Health Service, and allow British businesses to be at the forefront of new technology.The Tories must show real progress on housing and welfare reform.Nobody in the Government should imagine they’ll romp to victory in an election just because they’re up against Jeremy Corbyn’s Venezuela-flavoured socialism.The Tories shouldn’t give a single thought to an election this summer.But they must start building a track record that can win a General Election in the years to come.NO doubt about it, Nissan’s decision not to build the X-Trail in Sunderland is a blow to UK Plc.But it is not, as inexplicably smug Remainers are crowing, entirely due to Brexit.It’s as much about Brits increasingly not buying diesel cars as it is about our future trading relationships with the Continent.And the joy with which some on the left are greeting the news is perverse. title: remainer lies no deal anarchy
story: It’s not just the latest cobblers they seized on about the Queen being whisked to safety from rioting hordes descending on Buckingham Palace when food and medicines run out.It’s David Cameron pretending back in  that a Remain vote would empower him to fix the EU, asBrussels was remotely interested in reform.It’s George Osborne’s Project Fear tosh about an immediate crash after a Leave vote. title: nissan sunderland plant loses x trail
story: The Business Secretary finally revealed the package of taxpayer cash promised in  to persuade Japanese execs to expand production in the North-East.Nissan this weekend scrapped part of the plan – abandoning a vow to make a new diesel X-Trail at the site from .It will still make a new Qashqai model in the North-East.But red-faced Mr Clark yesterday admitted the Government would be forcing and said Brexit uncertainty had played a part.At one point he quoted Margaret Thatcher’s words when she opened Nissan’s factory in the  - that Britain’s position in Europe as a reason the company was choosing to invest.He said: “Nissan commented on the need for us to come together and resolve the question of our future trade relations with the EU.“I believe their advice should be listened to and acted upon.”But challenged by a string of Labour MPs, Mr Clark told them thatthey cared about the car industry they should back the PM’s Brexit agreement.The UK has traditionally been a launchpad to title: half of brits are going to be short sighted after spending too much time looking at phones
story: David Allamby said half the population could have myopia by  given the amount of time children are spending with their phones – up from  per cent now.One in ten could be at risk of torn retinas or even losing their sight.Mr Allamby of Focus Clinics said Ministers had to encourage children to put down their devices and get “outside”.A survey in Ireland three years ago found the proportion of kids suffering from myopia has doubled from . per cent to . per cent in the past  years.He said: “We are sleepwalking into an epidemic.“Screen time isn’t just affecting the mental health of school children it could also be ruining their eyesight too. We face a tsunami of short-sightedness.”Academics argue that modern lestyles are putting a huge strain on the ciliary muscle – which ends up ening the eye. This in turn increases the risk of glaucoma, retinal tears and even detachment.Mr Allamby said the concern was the growing risk of Brits developing problems at a younger age. “The younger these problems start, the more serious they become at a later date.”Experts warn that modern lestyles – at-desk working and a lack of daylight – has led to a sharp rise in eyesight issues around the world.Nearly  per cent of  year-old conscripts in South Korea were found to have myopia.The Sun on Saturday revealed Chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies will recommend limiting kids to two-hours-a-time on their devices.Schools Minister Nick Gibb has also separately called for a ban on pupils taking smartphones into school.Digital Minister Margot James is also later today expected to confirm a bid to force social media firms by law to sign a code of conduct protecting young and vulnerable users.

title: raf tornado jets fly last time defending britain
story: They are due to be replaced by Typhoons after spending  years defending Britain.After entering service in  the jets have been used all over the world - most recently bombing Isis with missiles to push the terrorist group back through Syria and Iraq.Squadron members were welcomed back by family and friends as they landed this afternoon at RAF Marham, Norfolk.Originally named the Tornado GR the aircraft’s first use in live operations was during the Gulf War in , when  Tornado GRs were deployed from bases in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain.Later they were upgraded to the GR model, which has been used ever since over the skies of Kosovo, Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria.From now on they will only be used for training purposes over the UK, before the Typhoons officially take on the mantle in March.The new and improved RAF jets will make up the backbone of the UKs combat airfleet - joining the new fleet of F- Lightning jets.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said: It is with a heavy heart, but enormous pride, that we bid farewell to the Tornado from operations.This truly is the end of an era, having played a vital role in keeping Britain and its allies safe for four decades.They are flexible when flying with a mm gun for ied targets.The aircraft carry Paveway guided bombs and Brimstone and Storm Shadow missiles.They can reach top speeds of Mach . and fly to an altitude of ,ft.A Tornados wingspan is ftin and the jet is ftins in .But, after so long in service, it is only right that we now look to the future.The combination of our state-of-the art Fs and the Typhoon’s new weapon systems will keep us as a world leader in air combat for a generation.Chief of the Air Staff, Air Chief Marshal Sir Stephen Hillier said: My sincerest congratulations to the Tornado Force, ing home after more than  years of continuous commitment to defeating Daesh in Iraq and Syria - an exceptional effort from everyone, well done and thank you.As a Tornado GR pilot myself, I have seen the aircraft develop over its nearly  years of service into an outstanding combat aircraft, flown, maintained and supported by similarly outstanding air and groundcrew.The Tornado Force has been continuously deployed on operations since , serving with immense distinction in Iraq, Syria, Afghanistan, Libya and the Balkans.I will personally be very sad to see the Tornado retire, but it is time now to pass the baton to our next generation combat aircraft.The F-B Lightning is now operational and the Typhoon is now fully multi-role capable and able to take on the Tornado’s missions.We can all take immense pride in what the Tornado has achieved in defence of the nation over nearly four decades, and reflect back on the courage, commitment and achievements of everyone who has contributed to the success of this extraordinary aircraft.The RAF has already trialled its Typhoon and F- Forces’ abilities to work together.In a series of trials, the effectiveness of both s when operating alongside one another has been confirmed.With its larger payload and increased agility and range, the Typhoon will operate in concert with the stealthy F- and its next-generation sensors, delivering the UK a force ready to counter evolving threats in the global environment.

title: tourist snaps seal poo new zealand usb
story: Vets took a slab of faeces from a leopard seal and had it stored in a freezer for a year before researchers started to analyse the mass for scientic research.But while sting the scat from feathers, seaweed and other junk they discovered something large and hard inside - a memory stick.Incredibly, after drying it out for a few weeks they were able to access all of its contents - including photos of sea lions at Porpoise Bay in Caitlins, as well as a video of a mum and baby frolicking in the shallows.The only clue of the person filming was the nose of a blue kayak shting through the waters, and a red and black boot poking out on the side of the boat.The footage is thought to have been taken in November , when a local vet checking on the health of a skinny seal picked up a sample.Seal faeces is said to be as good as gold for researchers, who can use the faeces to assess the health and diet of the animals.Volunteer Jodie Warren, who analysed the scat, was unimpressed by the holidaymaker in question. “It is very worrying that these amazing Antarctic animals have plastic like this inside them, she told the NIWA.The National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research said theof the USB stick would come with a price - a new sample of scat to continue their research.They added: The more we can find out about these creatures, the more we can ensure they are looked after.

story: Current hour-long ops see heated metal put into the urethra and used to cut the prostate — risking incontinence and impotence.But a new therapy for the non-cancerous ailment uses a tube to blast steam at affected glands.  It shrinks them by up to a third, has fewer side effects and takes  minutes. title: hatton garden basil caught camera chatting leader cops
story: Jurors heard how Michael Seed, , allegedly met John “Kenny” Collins in public parks on two occasions soon after the robbery.Just over , items of jewellery, gold, watches and bundles of valuable stones were later found in Seed’s bedroom following his arrest in March last year, it was alleged.Woolwich Crown Court was also told that Seed had consistently similar “reliable characteristics” to Basil’s “particular habitual gait” seen on CCTV during the Easter  heist.Prosecutor Philip Evans, QC, said a chiropodist and podiatrist reviewed police surveillance footage of Seed and compared it with CCTV of Basil from the record-breaking safety deposit box centre raid.Mr Evans added: “The expert noted the right leg movement and position of the foot and lower limb have a similar appearance at ious stages of the gait cycle in both sets of footage…“It is the expert’s opinion that there is strong evidence to support the proposition that Seed is Basil.”Mr Evans also said  items found at Seeds home were positively identied by safety deposit box owners as theirs – with  more described as being “consistent” to valuables stolen from them.Those items were valued overall at £,. by Wilsons Auctioneers, said Mr Evans.Jurors heard that Basil played a key role in the £million heist, and was one of two bandits to tunnel through a small hole into the vault.CCTV cameras captured Basil wearing a blue boiler suit, white gloves and carrying a black bin bag on his shoulder to shield his face from cameras, the court heard.He was disguised with a wig, face mask and earphones as he broke in through the main door of - Hatton Garden before letting accomplices in through a side fire exit during the raid carried out over two nights.Basil played the main role in disabling the alarm system and fellow gang members paid tribute to his skills during a covert police recording, the court heard.Mr Evans said a large number of books on electronics and surveillance were found along with covert audio and vibration recording devices during the search of Seed’s home in Islington, North London.Jurors also heard DNA profiles on a glove discovered at the scene of a similar £million raid at Mayfair jewellers Chatila in  allegedly links Seed to the raid with convicted Hatton Garden thieves Daniel Jones and Terry Perkins.Jones pleaded guilty to the break-in at the jewellers while Perkins died while awaiting trial, the court heard.Seed denies two charges of conspiracy to commit burglary and one charge of conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property.The trial continues." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   .main_image.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E"  How the Hatton Garden heist was executed

title: couple make gofundme page pay wedding
story: Cash-strapped Natalie Borg and Richard McMurray have so far raised £ for their big day on April .The former belly dancer and her fiance have been working overtime and even flogged their belongings to pay for everything.But with only three months to go they are falling short of their final bills and launched the appeal two weeks ago.Posting on GoFundMe, the couple said: We’ve done the math and are still short ofto cover our outgoings for our planned wedding on Saturday th April .Despite throwing all our wages at the wedding costs, selling our belongings and taking as many extra shts at work as are available we are still falling short of our final bills.As we can’t put off the wedding for another few months -we are asking in lieu of any wedding gtsyou are able to please contribute anything to our costs for the day that would be amazing.They added: Final payments we are are still trying to cover are mainly for the venue, photographer, cake and dress alterations.We have no honeymoon budget and not worrying about this just want to be able to cover our bills for the day so it can go ahead.Thank you you in advance to anyone able to help.The pair, who got engaged in January last year, have raised £ towards their target in two weeks.And theyve already managed to pay for their wedding rings, registry and favours - as well as cash towards the venue, dress alterations, hair and makeup.To help them afford their big day, visit their fundraising page here.

title: rolf harris walks primary school waves confronted teacher
story: The shamed former TV star, , was told to leave by the head teacher of the school in Maidenhead, Berks.A witness, who took pictures of Harris stalking the grounds, told the Mirror: “I couldn’t believe what I was seeing.”The disgraced entertainer - who served three years in prison for a string of historical sex offences - shook hands with the head teacher before he was ordered off the site, the paper says.Richard Jarrett, head of Oldfield Primary School, insisted Harris had no access to the pupils and informed the police.But parents are outraged that he was able to wave and smile at their children.Mr Jarret said: “We’ve got a wood sculptor working close to the road at the moment and Rolf Harris lives about three doors down from the school.He must have seen him [the sculptor] and come into the school area.He had no access to the children whatsoever.Harris explained that he was there to pick up some wood from the sculptor - but Mr Jarret told him: You need to go.Askedhe was concerned about the paedo waving at children, the teacher replied: I was not there at the time to stop him waving at the children.”Shamed Animal Hospital star Harris was sentenced in June  to five years nine months in prison for a dozen indecent assaults against four teenage girls between  and .He was released on license after three years in May  - with his sentence running out in March next year.Harris is thought to have been placed on the Sex Offenders Register - but it is not clearhe will have breached this by entering the school grounds.Aussie Rolf was photographed outside the school at about noon on Tuesday wearing a red jacket similar to the one he wore in his infamous mugshot.The passer-by who took the snaps said: I could not believe what I was seeing. A convicted paedophile should not be in the grounds of a primary school.“He was waving at the children through the window. I think they were on lunch or maybe in class.They were waving back at him and clearly had no idea who he was.”And a furious mum of two said: “For him to just be able to freely walk in is not a good thing.If you’re a paedophile you can’t be going near a school. I’m disgusted.”The Ministry of Justice said: “When sex offenders are released they are subject to strict licence conditions and are liable to be ed to custody for breaching them.We are looking into these reports and will take appropriate action.”A police spokesman said: “Thames Valley Police was called to Oldfield Primary School at around .pm today.“A report was made that a man was on the site of the school.An officer attended the scene but no offence was committed. title: spanish patrol boat stand off navy gibraltar
story: The episode had echoes of historic maritime victories against the Spanish by Admiral Lord Nelson at Trafalgar in  and Sir Francis Drake against the Armada in .In yesterday’s incident tiny HMS Sabre was involved in manoeuvres with a Royal Navy RHIB, when the Spanish vessel - the Tornado - blatantly sailed into the training drill yesterday morning where it stayed for two hours.As it passed into territorial waters the Spanish national anthem could be heard over Channel , a maritime communications frequency but it was not clear where it had come from.The captain of HMS Sabre warned the intruder away but it did not impact on the exercise.A Royal Navy insider confirmed the Spanish national anthem had been heard by radio operators at the Royal Navy base on Gibraltar.A source said:HMS Sabre politely requested the Spanish vessel, which is a good bit larger than she is, to leave Gibraltars territorial waters with a sovereignty warning. They extend for three miles around Gibraltar and initially it ignored the request which was made several times but she did eventually sail away after a couple of hours.Screenshots from shipping websites show how Tornado left the Spanish port of Ceuta yesterday morning before doubling back and heading towards Gibraltars Europa Point, clearly entering the exercise area.The rocky outcrop has been a British territory for more than  years and has been hotly disputed with Madrid and tensions have risen in the run up to Brexit.Last week colony in the UK and the EU launched into a new war of words over the Rock today as Gibraltar was branded a draft laws to give visa-free travel to Britons after March th.Downing Street swtly moved to slap down the jibe which is the latest ploy by Spain to take advantage of Brexit to stake its claim on the Rock.In yesterdays exercise - which was widely advertised by the Gibraltar authorities - ships were warned that a high speed manoeuvring and blank firing would take place.Passing ships who needed to contact the Royal Navy vessels involved were advised to use Channel  - which the Spanish did to broadcast their national anthem.A source in Gibraltar told The Sun:Spain is supposed to be a NATO ally but it now does this during an exercise - a clear infringement of Gibraltar territorial waters and it comes just weeks after they let Russian ships use their ports when they were asked not to.HMS Sabre issued a sovereignty warning to Tornado after it entered Gibraltar territorial waters and ordered her to leave immediately - there was an exercise going on and they would have known plus channel  was used to broadcast their national anthem. Its a clear provocation from Spain.Last night the Royal Navy referred all enquiries to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.In a statement the FCO said:We can confirm an incursion by the Spanish navy occurred this morning. As with all incursions, the Royal Navy challenged the vessel. When challenged, the Spanish navy vessel subsequently left British Gibraltar Territorial Waters. Incursions are a violation of sovereignty, not a threat to it.We have no doubt about our sovereignty over Gibraltar. The UK will never enter into arrangements under which the people of Gibraltar would pass under the sovereignty of another state against their wishes, nor enter into a process of sovereignty negotiations with which Gibraltar is not content.”The Spanish Government in Madrid and the Spanish Embassy in London was also contacted for comment but there was no immediate reply.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paramedic 23 lips double in size after mystery condition leaves her struggling to breathe
story: Lydia OConnor, , can be hit by the potentially fatal symptoms at any moment without any warning.The idiopathic urticaria sufferer was previously believed to have a nut allergy, after suffering a similar reaction for six days aged .But her condition was diagnosed after she was hospitalised in ­intensive care for four days ­following a reaction last year.Lydia, from Ballincollig, in Ireland, went on to suffer head-to-toe hives for six months, ranging from the size of a pin-prick to covering her stomach, and at their worst forcing her to go to hospital every week.Her symptoms mysteriously disappeared in August, leaving her relieved but also fearful they could come back at any point.The student, who lives in Chelmsford said: I came out in a rash from head to toe, it happened in an evening almost straight away.My lips definitely doubled in size, it was terrying because I didnt know what was happening.When I was admitted to the ICU, I thought I was having a severe allergic ­reaction like anaphylaxis, because I was struggling to breathe, and my tongue and lips were so swollen.Medication took down the ­swelling but the next day it all came back while I was in ­intensive care, then it continued to repeat over and over again.After five days in hospital and tests, the allergen markers in my blood werent raised, which ­indicated that it wasnt an allergic reaction. I was told Ive idiopathic urticaria, meaning it can start without a cause.Lydia was completely debilitated by the bizarre allergy, which affected all of her limbs. Yet despite trying everything she could think of to eliminate potential ­triggers, she couldnt find a cause.She explained: The daily rashes affected my whole body, I would wake up with them every day, they were really itchy and large.They even covered the palms of my hands and soles of my feet, it made me feel unwell, as I was so exhausted from being unable to sleep due to being so itchy.I couldnt see any identiable causes — I changed my bedsheets, my diet, my body wash, shampoo, make-up and everything.Thankfully, the rash started to subside in August — and has now disappeared ­completely. However, she constantly fears that the mystery condition will ­reappear.She said: Im worried it will come back next year as it started during the cold spell in the UK, so I do wonderits related to snow and cold weather.Im delighted that I dont have to deal with it any more — training to be a paramedic is full on and when youre with the public, people commentDuring Lydias battle with the rashes, strangers have treated her dferently.She explained: You could see people looking at my rash hoping they didnt catch it.No one said anything until when I was on ambulance ­placement — where you wear short sleeves — so could see my arms and chest.When I went to take someones blood pressure, she told me, Dont touch me, I dont want to catch it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: second eu referendum second brexit vote
story: The humiliating defeat raised questions over the possibility of a second referendum. But could that happen and how would it work May said on January  that a second referendum could threaten the UKs social cohesion.The PM made the statement as she unveiled her plan B Brexit deal to MPs in the House of Commons.She said a second referendum would set a dficult precedent and that the implications for the country were serious.On January  on MPs backed Mays plan B deal as long as she clock ticks down to the UKs scheduled departure from the European Union on March .European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker described the Agreement reached after  months of negotiation last November as the best and only deal possible.And he told MEPs in the European Parliament in Brussels: The debate and votes in the House of Commons yesterday do not change that.The Withdrawal Agreement will not be renegotiated.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has not ruled out calling for a second referendum in a U-turn after Mays plan B Brexit deal statement on January .He has repeatedly demanded a general election and not supported a second referendum until Labour MPs openly defied him.But on January , it emerged Corbyn has given his backing to Labour MPs plan for a second Brexit referendum.Its claimed Corbyn now wants the Government to give MPs the final say on whether there should be a second vote.If a majority back a referendum, Parliament in turn could force Theresa May to hold a new vote that could lead to Brexit being reversed, reports the .Corbyn had banned his party MPs from speaking with May about Brexit until she scrapped a no-deal Brexit, but Chuka Umunna and Chris Leslie went to No on January  for talks.After MPs rejected Mays deal on January , Corbyn tabled a vote of no confidence in the PMs government -it passed it could have triggered a general election.However, May narrowly survived the vote by  votes.Betfair has put the odds at   that there will be another Brexit referendum by the end of this year and   there wont.Bookmaker Betfair has odds of   the UK won’t leave the EU by March  and   odds that we will.Ladbrokes has put the odds at   that the UK will leave the EU without a deal before April , .A poll carried out by YouGov on January  revealed that  per cent said they would vote Remainthere was a second referendum,   per cent say they would leave and  per cent would be undecided.After Parliament rejected Mays Withdrawal Agreement,  per cent said she should resign,  per cent said she should stay as PM and  per cent did not know.The question was put to , British adults.The SNP have said they would back a so-called Peoples Vote and a number of Conservative MPs have also backed one.So there could be a majority in Parliament for it but a second referendum will not happen quickly and the first stage is for there to be an Act of Parliament.That will require the backing of a majority of MPs and it took seven months before Parliament signed off the previous referendum legislation in .Last time around there was a four-month period between the then Prime Minister David Cameron announcing the referendum in February , and the vote taking place on  June.But the Electoral Commission has said in future there should be at least a six-month gap to allow enough time to register campaigns and put counting officers in place.There is also the question of what to do about Article .This could be avoidedthe EU agreed to extend the Article  deadline - but that would need to be unanimously agreed by all EU member states.Then there is the question of what to put on the ballot paper.If there are three questions - for example accept a negotiated Brexit deal stay in the EU or leave with no deal - then just  per cent could decide the winning option.The first referendum on EU membership took place in .Two-thirds of votersbacked the continued membership of the European Economic Community, which the UK had joined only two years before.Under Harold Wilsons leadership, the Labour Party was trying to present to the public a dferent version of EEC membership to get a better deal.The EEC was integrated into the European Union after it was created in .In the summer of , Britain voted to leave the EU after .million people backed Leave compared to .million Remain voters.

title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border vote latest
story: The Prime Minister spoke at the Northern Irish border on Tuesday February  to deliver a speech regarding the border. Heres the latest on the tricky talking point.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It would avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.Also, it would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.But it is unclearthe UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries while the backstop endured.And it is feared the UK would end up being trapped in the customs union. The PM is now hoping to negotiate a way around this.On January  the Prime Minister succeeded in a parliamentary vote which united her party behind a plan to rewrite the deal to address concerns about the Irish backstop.In dramatic scenes, Tory and rebel Labour MPs voted by a margin of  to  to back a plan - the Brady amendment - which requires the PM to replace the Agreements controversial backstop with alternative arrangements to keep the Irish border open after Brexit.But senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin resisted the demand from May as the clock ticks down to the UKs departure from the European Union on March .Speaking in Belfast yesterday, the PM vowed to back a joint bid for the  World Cup by all the countries of the British Isles.And she pledged that after Brexit, the UK will have a closer relationship with Irelandthan with any other European country.Mrs May also risked angering her MPs by suggesting she might not ditch the backstop after all.In a speech aimed squarely at winning goodwill from Dublin, the PM said: Our relationship with Ireland is deeper than our relationship with any of the other . It is uniquely rooted in ties of family, history and geography.The recent past has been a moment of reflection in the UK and Ireland as we have commemorated the centenary of a series of key events in our shared history.Today those ties of family and friendship between our countries are more important than they have ever been.And I believe there is a yearning in the hearts of all the peoples of these islands for a close and trusting relationship between all of us, and an absolute horror that we should take even a single step backwards in the progress we have collectively achieved.She proposed annual meetings between the British and Irish governments after Brexit to ensure the two countries work closely together.She promised to lobby Mrs May on the issue when they hold talks in Belfast tomorrow.She said: We will be reiterating our opposition to the current backstop. And the fact that Parliament has now backed that position means that she has a clear mandate to go back to Brussels.The current backstop is toxic to those of us living in Northern Ireland, and indeed for unionists right across the United Kingdom, because it would cause the break-up of the United Kingdom into the medium and longer term.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn second brexit referendum frankenstein
story: In a huge blow for Remainers who hope that the Labour boss will eventually throw his weight behind another Brexit vote, the uncovered video shows him slamming the bloc.And he mocked the idea of a second referendum too, saying he had a feeling theyre going to keep on voting to get the answer they want after Ireland narrowly rejected adopting the Lisbon Treaty, a video unearthed by the Red Roar revealed.In a rally in  he branded the EU as subservient to Nato and said he did not want to live in a European empire of the st century.At the event organised by the Irish Anti-War movement he said he wished Britain would have a referendum too on whether to accept the new demands from the bloc.Backbencher Mr Corbyn blasted: Under the terms of the Lisbon Treaty, Europe will become subservient to the wishes of Nato and the aims of Nato.We are creating for ourselves here one massive Frankenstein, which will damage all of us in the long run.Mr Corbyns Remain supporters think he will cave and back a fresh vote to stay in the European Union.But this video shows the Labour boss true colours - and shows that hopes he will come out in favour of a second Brexit referendum to overturn the result are incredibly slim.Even Brexiteer Nigel Farage praised the speech, saying he was a real Eurosceptic.He went on: His role will be crucial over the next few weeks.Will the real Jeremy Corbyn please stand up And SNP MP Stewart McDonald tweeted earlier: He and Farage were singing from the same song sheet, albeit from dferent ends of the political spectrum.Mr Corbyn has a long history of Euroscepticism and famously was slammed for taking a back seat in the  EU referendum.Since then hes had to walk a tightrope over Brexit to try and keep all sides of his party happy.BRITAIN should continue allow free movement in some forms after we leave, Sir Keir Starmer has said.In a signicant softening of Labours position the Shadow Brexit Secretary called for Britain to allign with the EU after we leave.He said people would be willing to accept free movement of people with some restrictions - like advertising a job locally first, or bringing family members over.Sir Keir told the BBC: If somebody is coming to do a job and it needs to be done and it has been advertised locally beforehand with nobody able to do it, then most people would say I accept that.Most people say thatyou are coming to join your family that is something I can accept. Most people would saysomebody wants to come here and study and it is genuine then of course please come and study. In fact lets celebrate that.Theresa May has vowed that free movement will end after Brexit, and has insisted that Britain will finally be able to take back control of our borders once again after we leave.Voters said that immigration was one of the major factors in voting to leave the bloc.Labour has fiercely opposed Mrs Mays Brexit deal but stopped short of endorsing a second referendum.They say they will only back another votethey cant force through a general election to seize power.A spokesperson for Mr Corbyn said today: Jeremy’s criticisms of the Lisbon Treaty over a lack of democracy in the EU, its strengthening of neoliberal economic policies and potential military expansion are well known.That’s why he campaigned both to remain and reform in the  EU referendum, so it could live up to the promise of a social Europe.He is clear that a public vote must remain an option on the table to prevent the damage of a No Deal exit from the EU.

title: no deal brexit would be fault of stubborn eurocrats playing hardball top brexiteer storms
story: Chris Grayling launched a barnstorming attack on Brussels sayingwe left without a deal they would be entirely to blame, and not us.Just hours before it was revealed that Theresa May will dash to Brussels this week for talks with the EU over her deal, he said that Britain was doing all it could to try and reach agreement.But he warned in an interview with The Daily :  If they are not willing to compromise,theyre not willing to work with us to find common ground - it will be down to themthere is no deal.And he added: We want to work with the EU to reach a deal butthey are not prepared to do that - they will have to take responsibility that we are heading towards a no-deal exit.The EU have repeatedly insisted that they wont budge on the Irish border - saying the deal is done and dusted.He insisted Mrs May would be tough in the upcoming talks, but that there would be no chance of Article  being delayed at all.Ive been in every Cabinet meeting and theres been no conversation about delaying post-March , he said.We are not delaying Article .And Mr Grayling also slapped down scaremongering reports of food shortages after we leave the EU by saying: No, Im not stockpiling.Trade would continue to flow freely after we leave no matter what happens, we insisted.So its not a case that once we leave the EU that food supplies will suddenly dry up.His comments were echoed today by ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab.In an interview with ConservativeHome this morning he said that: It will be important for people to see thatthe EU remain stubbornly intransigent, they are the ones courting the WTO exit.People understand that we need to leave on th March. Whether they voted Leave or Remain, the one thing you hear is get this thing done and dusted.Leaving without a deal wouldnt be the end of the world, but it wouldnt be a walk in the park, he said, which is also the view of Roberto Azevedo, the Director of the World Trade Organisation.Mr Raab even hinted that Britain could be SAFER after Brexit - because well be able to refuse entry to anyone that border officials are worried about.Britain is due to leave the EU on March  no matter what happens, but the PM has promised to go back and ask for changes to the hated Northern Irish backstop.Mrs May is still clinging to her deal, but accepts that MPs dont want it in its current form.She will come up with the plan to take to Brussels later this week which involves major changes to the Northern Ireland border.

title: brexit work begins to turn m20 into huge lorry park if we leave with no deal
story: Transport Minister Jesse Norman has told MPs that Highways England will “start installing contraflow infrastructure” such as steel barriers and new signs shortly.Under the Government plans – dubbed “Operation Brock” - a  –mile stretch of the east-bound carriageway could be used to hold , trucks in the case of chaos at Dover.So-called “non-port” traffic will then travel both ways on the west-bound route.The revelations come a day after HM Customs  Exciserevealed it would wave through EU goods that arrive at  ports across the UK in a No Deal to avoid jams.In a ministerial statement today, Mr Norman said the European Commission had indicated hauliers would keep “basic rights” to take shipments to the EUthe UK leaves without a deal.But he added there was still no final agreement with Brussels.And he said the Government may have to strike inidual deals with member states to keep trucks on the road.Haulage bosses have slammed Ministers for the delays in producing a clear plan of what could happen in a No Deal.They claim the French are still in the dark about what the Department for Transport is considering.Today, Mr Norman said a mere  annual permits may be available for hauliers to trade in the EUBrussels forces Britain to rely on permits.But he added: “It is important to be clear that the Government does not expect to rely on ECMT permits for hauliers to travel to EU member states, and is also making preparations to agree and implement bilateral arrangements for access,necessary.”

title: brexit secret high tech irish border
story: Officials from DexEU have been quietly working on the blueprint – drawn up by Japanese firm Fujitsu – for  months.But, it has been rapidly dusted down in the last week after MPs voted to replace the current Irish backstop with a dferent one that could involve “alternative arrangements”.An  page briefing on the explosive Futitsu plan has been leaked to The Sun.Named the ‘Drive Through Border Concept’, it ensures there is no need for any physical checks on the border or hard infrastructure.Instead, a tracking system monitors vehicles on designated routes as they cross from Northern Ireland to the Republic via GPS as well as number plate recognition cameras.Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay is studying the plan closely.It has also been circulated among a working group of senior Tory Leavers and Remainers who have come together to propose a new backstop based on stand-off customs checks, dubbed the Malthouse Compromise.EU critics of the alternative arrangements to change the backstop have claimed the technology doesn’t yet exist to police the border and are years away.But The Sun’s revelation today heaps more pressure on PM Theresa May to agree to push the border plan during talks in Brussels tomorrow.The Sun has also learned that the working group has also been briefed on a goods tracking system in Africa that has used the same technology for the last  months.Designed to ward off bandits and hijackers, the Regional Electronic Cargo Tracking System operates across borders between Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda.A Tory minister involved in the talks told The Sun: “Given that we can land a probe the size of a fridge on Mars, it can’t be beyond us to devise an imperceptible system for a  mile border”.Fujitsu have promised DexEU that proof of concept trials on the border with  hauliers testing their system will be ready by March .Marked ‘Restricted – Commercial in Confidence’, the document also reveals the plan allowsProof of concept ready for a trial by March ,  hauliers to test itThe only infrastructure needed to run the system are number plate recognition cameras on approach roads to the border itself.But that could anger nationalists who will say it break Mrs May’s promise of no infrastructure at all.The Fujitsu system could also be rejected by the Northern Irish, who have a deep dislike of state surveillance that dates back to the Troubles era.A DExEU spokesperson said: Throughout this process the Government has explored options with firms and experts for proposals to solve the issue of the Irish border.As the Political Declaration makes clear, the UK and the EU have committed to exploring what alternative arrangements to the backstop might look like. We are also clear that those solutions can not include new border infrastructures.”THE French last night told Transport Secretary Chris Grayling he was not welcome at Calais after he announced plans to ert ferries from the port under a no deal Brexit.The head of the French port Jean-Marc Puissesseau said he was never welcome toto the port as he accused Mr Grayling of being “completely disrespectful” for failing to forewarn the French about his contingency plans.The Sun revealed in October that Mr Grayling had drawn up plans to lease space on ferries so the Government can redirect them to Rotterdam and Belgian ports in case of logjams at Calais.Mr Puissesseau said the Transport Secretary gave no warning about the proposals - despite attending a meeting with port officials who insisted they could cope with extra customs checks that would be neededBritain crashes out of the EU without a deal.The French port chief told the : “Mr Grayling came to us in November and asked uswe would be ready. We told him ‘yes’, though we did not know as much as we know today. He did not tell us that he wanted to reduce the activity [at Calais].“It is not fair at all, it is completely disrespectful. I don’t want to see him again.”Mr Puissesseau added that Calais had injected fresh cash for a new traffic light system that will help combat logjams under a no deal Brexit.Green will be for lorries that have the correct paperwork, amber for those who are not sure and red for vehicles with no paperwork.He joked that Mr Grayling was so unpopular that he would also have to pass throught the traffic light systemhe did attempt to visit Calais.Mr Puissesseau said: “I have heard he is ‘failing Grayling’...He will have to have a declarationhe comes to Calais. He will have to go through the orange lane.”The anti-Brexit Best for Britain group last night said the move effectively meant Mr Grayling was “banned” from Calais.One of its supporters and Labour MP Virendra Sharma said: “Surely this is peak Chris Grayling - only this time he’s gone international.“All he needs to do now is release a statement blaming everyone  and his predictable path of chaos will be complete.”A spokesman from the Department for Transport said: “While the Transport Secretary strongly supports work across Government with the EU to ensure a deal is reached, he will also continue to lead the DfT to ensure all contingencies are prepared for concerning Brexit.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit sir keir starmer immigration
story: Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said he believed most people would accept free movementEU nationals had a job to come to.And he insisted all firms should do is advertise locally first before flying migrants in from the Continent.He added that Labour could “explore” the so-called Norway-style Brexit – where the UK would have to offer free movement to workers.Sir Keir said: “I think most people would agree thatsomebody is coming to do a job, and it needs to be done, and it’s been advertised locally beforehand with nobody to do it, then most people would say ‘I would accept that’.He added that “most people” would also accept people coming to Britain on grounds of family reunication – or study.Labour’s Election Manesto in  accepted free movement would come to an end when the UK leaves the EU.Sir Keir at the time admitted there would have to be “change” at the border.But just months later Sir Keir said Labour would accept “easy movement”.He now suggests letting any EU migrant enterthey have a job no Brit wants. Which sounds sensible enough. Except it encourages firms which have profited from cheap EU labour for years to offer rock-bottom pay they know Brits won’t take but migrants will.It’s free movement by another name. A backdoor betrayal of one of the central Brexit demands, control of our borders.Leavers are deserting Labour. Corbyn could do worse than sack his Brexit chief. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour call ban political facebook
story: NewsLabour call for ban on political Facebook ads that target UK citizens from overseasTom Watson said: “I know Silicon Valley companies didn’t set out to undermine democracy. But they didn’t stop it, and they continue to profit from it"ShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Social media giants should ban overseas political advertisers from targeting UK citizens to improve digital democracy, Labour will say today.Under their plans, digital adverts and social media bots would have to be clearly labelled so online consumers know who is behind them. It comes as part of a drive to ‘clean up’ the internet and give the public more power online in the wake of the Vote Leave data harvesting scandal. Shadow culture secretary Tom Watson will say: “I know Silicon Valley companies didn’t set out to undermine democracy. But they didn’t stop it, and they continue to profit from it. “This is a matter of national security. Disinformation ides our society, damages our faith in the media, and distorts electoral outcomes. We need to counter this.”   Labour is also proposing a new digital bill of rights to allow citizens to exercise more control over how their data is collected and monetized. “We have the right to know who is trying to influence our views, and how they are trying to do it,” he said. “Agents of disinformation amply their lies through targeted digital adverts and social media bots.” There would be a new legal duty to remove illegal content with the supervision of regular judicial review and a transparent process, including fast-track appeals. It comes after the Government yesterday revealed that social media firms would be forced by law to sign a code of conduct protecting young and vulnerable users. A White Paper on online harms will be published by the end of winter setting out expectations for firms, followed by a consultation over the summer. Digital minister Margot James said: “There is far too much bullying, abuse, misinformation and manipulation online as well as, I’m afraid, serious organised crime. “For too long, the response of many of the large s has fallen short. “There have been no fewer than  voluntary codes of practice agreed with s since . “Where we are now, is an absolute indictment of a system which has relied far too little on the role of the law.”   Labour’s own plans for a duty of care currently go further as they are backed up by tough financial penalties.This means firms like Facebook , Google and Twitter could face fines of up to pound million a time for breaches such as those behind the death of -year-old Molly Russell.The teenager’s parents said last month that exposure to harmful content about depression and suicide online had led their daughter to suicide in . Labour is also proposing to give a new regulator, with statutory underpinning, powers to prevent market abuse and where necessary break up monopolies. It comes as former deputy PM Nick Clegg, new head of global affairs at Facebook, was invited to appear before MPs.

title: amber peat told teachers pot
story: NewsAmber Peat told teachers about pot-washing punishments before hanging herselfSchoolgirl Amber, , was found hanged in a hedgerow after she ran away from home following a row with her parents over chores, an inquest heardShareByHayley Coyle:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAmber Peat went missing from her home in Mansfield in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old schoolgirl who hanged herself had told teachers about pot-washing punishments at home, an inquest has heard. Alarm bells were ringing at Amber Peats school just months before she was found hanged in a hedgerow, the hearing was told. Concerns about the teenager, from Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, were reported to a safeguarding team at her local council. These included claims she had made to teachers at school that she had been forced to wash every pot in her house as a punishment. The inquest has heard she was also made to wear baggy tracksuit bottoms to school because she forgot to wash her school clothes. A second call to the team listed a series of alleged incidents reported by Amber to her form tutor that had happened at home, one of which was a claim her stepdad Danny Peat had woken the schoolgirl at .pm and made her clean the floor of their house.   However, on neither occasion was Amber’s case escalated to the level of formal social care involvement, the hearing was told today. This led to coroner Laurinda Bower saying she was ‘concerned’ about how the system operated. Amber’s body was discovered in June , three days after she walked out of the home she shared with mum Kelly, stepdad Danny, and two younger siblings. The inquest into her death has heard how she ran away from home following a row with her parents over chores. The hearing, which is being held in Nottingham, was earlier told her parents waited almost eight hours before they finally reported her missing in the early hours of the morning. Ms Bower was told two calls were made from Queen Elizabeth School in Mansfield, which Amber attended at the time of her death, to MASH before the tragedy – one in September , and another six months later.  Both times a worker took information from the callers – one of which was a key worker at the school and the other its vice principal - and handed it on to a qualied social worker. But the inquest was told the case didn’t pass a “threshold” that would have triggered statutory social services intervention. The coroner told MASH group manager Teresa Godfrey: “In the world of safeguarding there should have been an explicit conversation about risk.” The first call to the safeguarding unit was made by Queen Elizabeth vice principal Karen Green. Ms Green said she knew the Peats had been involved with a similar team in Derby, where they used to live, adding: “This family has moved around quite a bit and people have started to work with them and as soon as they start to work with them, the family move.”  The teacher added Amber had mentioned a “big secret” at home she wasn’t allowed to talk about – which turned out to be her stepdad had been jailed for tax fraud – and that she had been subjected to the pot washing punishment. The inquest was told that Ms Green said: “This one is ringing alarm bells. It just does not feel right. My gut instinct is there is something not right here and I can’t put my finger on it.” A second call was made to the MASH team in March , two months before Amber’s death, by her school key worker Sharon Clay. She reported concerns over Amber wearing ill-fitting tracksuit bottoms to school, which the inquest has previously heard she was made to do by Mr Peat after failing to put her normal trousers in the wash, and bringing her items in a cheap plastic bag.  Ms Clay added that she thought Amber was being “emotionally abused” by her stepdad, who had also ordered her to wash the floors at .pm at night. MASH worker Joanna Shepherd, who took the call, said “you would need more incidents over a period of time” – adding she was not aware at the time of the “bigger picture” surrounding Amber. But Ms Bower askedany thought had been given to the impact it could have on Amberthe disclosures she’d made to her teacher were passed back to her parents, adding: “As we discuss this now, do you see the concerns I am raising ” Mrs Shepherd replied: “Yes. But I could not question the social worker on that.” The hearing was told that since Amber’s death procedures had been put in place, including better recording systems, that aimed to gather and collate information better. The inquest continues. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or byemailingjo@samaritans.org
