story: NewsGranddad waits  hours in AE - only to be told "go home, theres no doctor in house"Mohammed Nazir, , and his family have slammed the actions of Nottinghams Queens Medical Centre as "disgusting"ShareCommentsByBradley JollyMatt Jarram:,  FEB NewsMohammed Nazir allegedly faced an eight-hour wait in AE, only to be told to go home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A granddad with breathing dficulties allegedly waited eight hours in AE - only to be told: Go home, there is no doctor in the house.Mohammed Nazir, , had to wait from .pm to .am in a crowded waiting room to be seen, his family claim.The retired grandfather-of-nine, who has a number of conditions including angina, diabetes, high blood pressure and kidney disease, began to get breathless at his home on Friday. He was also struggling to speak, and his GP told him to go straight to Nottinghams Queens Medical Centre, Nottinghamshire Live reports.But despite the hospital having a government performance target - which aims for patients to be seen within four hours - Mohammed was allegedly forced to wait double that time.Now, his son Najeeb, , has blasted the NHS hospital.  At .am, he was told sorry you need to go home, there is no doctor. I am absolutely disgusted, he said. There needs to be some responsibility by the local management team that the provision is there. My dad has had a stroke before, and a heart attack, so I did not want to risk it and wanted him to be seen. The emergency departments head of service said a signicant increase in the number of very poorly patients requiring care has led to its services being under considerable pressure. He also acknowledged some emergency patients have experienced unacceptably long waits, although overcrowding has been signicantly reduced by an expansion.  But Najeeb, of Wollaton, Nottingham, claimed: Okay there is austerity in this country but we have paid for this service - my dad has paid national insurance and tax for more than  years. At am, I said we have been here quite a while and they said we cant help itthere is no doctors. It was a packed waiting room, some patients just got up and left including one man with an abscess on his leg. My dad was very uncomfortable and sat there quietly and he could not breathe properly. It was out of order. It is not fair on patients. We thought it was going to be a few hours. Mr Nazir had to go to a walk-in centre the next day.  Doctors told the pensioner he had a bad chest infection and he was given a course of antibiotics. Frank Coffey, head of service for the Emergency Department at Queens Medical Centre, said: “A signicant increase in the number of very poorly patients requiring care at our hospitals has meant that our services are under considerable pressure. Regrettably, some of our emergency patients have experienced unacceptably long waits although our newly-expanded Emergency Department has signicantly reduced the overcrowdingwhich means our patients are being cared for in a better, safer environment. “We are advising patients who are not suffering from serious and le-threatening illnesses to seek alternatives to our Emergency Department, such as GP surgeries, pharmacies or calling NHS  for advice.  Help us help you by choosing the right care choice andyou are unsure, please visit our website: www.nuh.nhs.uk emergency-department .”Problems with the newly-redesigned AE department at QMC have seen patient waiting times rise signicantly compared to last year. The existing emergency department regularly sees up to  patients per day – but was initially designed for .

title: hatton garden heist suspect can
story: NewsHatton Garden heist suspect can be identied by his odd walkMichael Seed, , was allegedly the brains behind the jewellery vault burglary, Woolwich Crown Court was toldShareByTom Pettor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA sketch of Michael Seed at an earlier court appearance "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Hatton Garden heist suspect known as “Basil” can be identied by his odd walk, a court has heard. Michael Seed, , is said to share the same gait as a burglar in a wig captured on CCTV during the poundmillion raid over the  Easter Bank Holiday. Seed was allegedly the brains behind the burglary, disabling the alarm, allowing the elderly villains to enter the vault, Woolwich Crown Court was told. Six men drilled in to take gems, cash and gold worth pound.million. Five have been convicted over the raid: Brian Reader, , John Collins, , Daniel Jones, , Carl Wood, , and Terry Perkins, who died last year aged .  CCTV cameras captured Basil in a blue boiler suit and disguised with the wig and mask, as he walked in through the main door of Hatton Garden Safe Deposit, Central London. Comparing that with covert footage of Seed, a shypodiatrist saw “strong evidence” to suggest they are the same man, said prosecutor Philip Evans QC. Mr Evans told jurors: “He concluded the ‘Basil’ footage showed someone with a particular habitual walk or gait, an abnormality in his right leg.” He said  items of jewellery shypotentially stolen from the Hatton Garden were found in Seed’s one-bed council flat in a raid in March . Officers found precision drills, a smelting machine and jewellery, gold, watches and gems valued at pound,.   Anti-surveillance gadgets and gold ingots like ones linked to Jones were also found at the Islington flat, where Seed lived alone just two miles from the diamond district, the court heard. Jurors were told he has no known income and was unemployed from , paid no tax and took no benefits. Recordings of Jones, Collins and Perkins supported the claim that Seed is Basil, the court heard. Jones was said to be referring to Seed’s “frugal lestyle” when he said gold, cash and “foreign money” from the raid would last Basil “forever, Tel, that will last him right through, he goes for the cheapest gaffs”. Another plank in the prosecution case is surveillance photos of Seed meeting Collins twice in the weeks after the burglary, the court heard.  Mr Evans also outlined “striking and compelling” similarities between Hatton Garden and a second high value raid Seed is charged with. The Chatila jewellery store in Bond Street was attacked on August Bank Holiday weekend in . Seed is alleged to have disabled two alarms, allowing four raiders to swipe around poundmillion worth of jewellery, along with pound, in cash. “These two offences required very specialist skills and knowledge,” he said. “The prosecution suggest that Mr Seed is one of those people.” Seed denies two charges of conspiracy to commit burglary and one charge of conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property. The trial continues.

title: hermit living scottish forest saved
story: NewsHermit living in Scottish forest saved after SOS signal is picked up in TexasThe mans emergency alert from his log cabin near near Fort Worth, Scotland, was detected , miles away in Houston, Texas, USAShareCommentsByMirror:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe man was winched away by mountain rescue workers after being found "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA hermit living in a remote forest in Scotland was rescued after his distress signal was picked up nearly , miles away. The elderly man, believed to be in his s, had lived alone in a log cabin near Fort Worth for many years. But he activated a distress beacon to send an SOS signal to tell emergency services he was in trouble. It was picked up , miles away at the International shyEmergency Response Coordination Centre in Houston, Texas, and relayed to the UK Coastguard. With no means of finding outit was a  alarm, the shyCoastguard sent up a helicopter from Prestwick, Ayrshire. A winchman found the man seriously ill in his cabin but the surrounding trees prevented him from being winched up. A mountain rescue team was instead sent in to bring him to a suitable area for winching.   Team leader John Stevenson said: “We got a call to take seven of us by helicopter to as close as the aircraft could land. “We reached the dwelling and took him by stretcher to the helicopter. “It was a cold night and the job took about  minutes. It was a very well coordinated rescue.” The pensioner was flown to Torlundy, where he was taken by shyambulance to hospital in Fort William. His condition was not known last night. Neil Blewett, aeronautical operations centre controller for HM Coastguard, said: “The satellites and the SPOT beacon saved his le because without any of those, we would not have known he needed urgent help.”

title: mum gives birth first baby
story: NewsFirst-time mum gives birth in backseat of husbands car - but he doesnt even realiseSonal Vasta, from Bolton, Manchester, says her husband didnt believe she was giving birth as they drove down a main roadShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSonal and Vik Vasta were astounded by the car birth "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A brave mum delivered her own baby on the backseat of her husband’s car - but he didnt even realise she was giving birth. First-time mother Sonal Vasta, , gave birth to little Mihan as her partner Vik, , drove his Audi in heavy traffic.She says Vik didnt believe she was delivering their child - but when she felt the head, she told him to pull over. The couple, of Bolton, Greater Manchester, had been to pregnancy hypnobirthing and yoga classes before the birth. They believe that is what kept Sonal supremely calm throughout. Sonal said: In my classes, I was told to envisage the place I wanted to give birth. Obviously, I didn’t exactly visualise a car birth.  “I was so calm that the midwives told me not to come into hospital. Even my husband didn’t believe I was in labour and he didn’t even stop the car for the birth. “We were driving down the main road and the next thing, I was holding a baby boy in my arms. Just two streets on, I felt the head and I told Vik to pull over. But he was saying: ‘We’re nearly there, just hold on.’ He didn’t believe I was giving birth.  When Sonal, a finance officer for Manchester City Council, experienced contractions on November , she rang midwives who allegedly told her she was too calm to be in labour. But within minutes, her waters had broken in her hubbys car just streets from their home. Vik and I both lost our dads and I like to think they were shining down on us, she said. The cord was round the baby’s neck and I was able to think clearly and loosen it. “I rubbed his back and he coughed and it was such a relief.  The mum added: We were on the phone to the hospital, and they were guiding us through it all. The midwives met us in the hospital car park and we were rushed inside. Mihan weighed lbs oz and was healthy. Vik, an accounts manager, said he and Sonals hypnobirthing and yoga classes helped his we remain calm. Vik is not so calm now after receiving the cleaning bill for his Audi! Sonal said. I’ve said we can never sell the car now. It’s full of memories.

title: mum too fat theme park
story: NewsMum too fat for theme park at  stone loses over THIRD of her body weightJenefer Gillam, , from West Sussex, saw her weight creep up after gorging on huge portions of quick-fix caloric food like ready-made pies and family sharing packs of crispsShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyErin Cardf:,  FEB NewsJenefer wanted to change her le after catching a glimpse of herself in the mirror at work "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who says she was too fat for theme park rides at  stone made an incredible transformation after losing more than a third of her body weight. Jenefer Gillam, , saw her weight creep up after gorging on huge portions of quick-fix caloric food. The NHS worker, from East Preston, West Sussex began experiencing breathlessness, aching joints and indigestion - and decided to overhaul her whole lestyle in  after catching a glimpse of herself in a lt at work. Jenefer said: I just thought – ‘Jenefer, you’re enormous. Determined to change, Jenefer, whose partner Glenn, , is a technology sales consultant, joined WW, formerly known as Weight Watchers, in early  and has since completely changed her diet - slimming down to a size  after an eight stone weight loss. Jenefer, mum to Ethan, , and Eva, seven, revealed: “Since losing the weight, I’ve bumped into colleagues from dferent offices, or friends that I don’t see regularly, and they haven’t even recognised me. I’ll get a blank look when I say hello, before they realise who I am.”   Struggling with her weight for much of her le, the super-slimmer admitted to embarking on ious dferent diets over the years, without much success. Her problem escalated after having children and when, in , she started studying for a Masters degree, juggling lectures with work and being a mum meant any notion of healthy eating and exercise took a back seat. She explained: “The weight crept on as I’d be sitting there in the evenings studying and grabbing quick fixes. “I did also eat fruit and vegetables and wasn’t one for takeaways or anything like that, but it was more the portion sizes that were the problem. My portions would be huge.” Most mornings, Jenefer would start with peanut butter on toast, before grabbing a coffee and a cake or bacon butty once she got to college. Then lunch would be a cheese-laden panini followed by comfort food for dinner, like a jacket potato piled high with toppings, or a pie. “I had a terrible crisp habit, too,” she said. “I could easily get through a family bag, then fib about it, saying the kids had eaten it.” Eventually, Jenefer reached her heaviest weight of st lb – although she said she still felt relatively confident.   But, in late , everything changed during a seemingly routine morning at her work in clinical services for the NHS. After taking the lt to avoid the stairs, she saw herself in the mirror and felt asshe was seeing the change in her body for the first time. “I thought to myself, ‘You’re fat, you’re getting out of breath easily – you have to do something.’ I’d been getting all sorts of health problems like aching knees and ankles, terrible indigestion and high cholesterol,” she said. “I knew I had to change for the sake of my kids. It was never about confidence. Even at my biggest, I always tried to make the best of myself with makeup and having my hair done – but I didn’t want anything to happen to me. I had to think of Ethan and Eva.” But, since joining WW, she has now lost eight stone and, at the end of , also started regularly working out at a local gym. “It does take courage to walk in there when you aren’t a skinny Minnie, as you worry what people will say,” she said. “I started out with quite gentle exercise, but now I go five times a week and do more high intensity classes like spinning. “I never thought I’d be able to do that.” Her body overhaul has also meant Jenefer has more fun with her children.   “The best thing about it is being able to keep up with the kids more. I can go swimming with them, or bike rides at the weekend, she said. “We can even go to theme parks now, when, on two occasions in the past, I was too heavy for the rides and had to get off. It was the most mortying thing – one of those moments where everybody is staring, and you just want the ground to swallow you up. “Now, I don’t even have to think about it.” With the help of the WW app, Jenefer has transformed her eating habits too, downloading healthy recipes and ensuring she eats a balanced diet, aided by their Smartpoints system. The apps built-in barcode scanner also means Jenefer is able to check food whilst in the supermarket to see how many points it would be worth - and can even win prizes for sticking to her plan through WWs new WellnessWins reward programme.   Now, breakfast will be nutrient-packed overnight oats - a favourite with fitness bloggers - followed by fresh home-cooked meals, such as butternut squash shepherds pie or garlicky chicken with vegetables. “I have a busy le, but this regime is manageable for me. I can find recipes I like and make them quickly and easily,” she said. “Now, when I look back, I can’t quite believe it’s me in old photos. I walk much taller these days and feel very proud. “For my th birthday just gone, I even wore a black sleeveless jumpsuit. It’s something I never dreamed I’d see myself in, but I felt fantastic.”For information, visit www.weightwatchers uk

title: pub owners brutal takedown customers
story: NewsPub owners brutal takedown of customers one-star TripAdvisor reviewThe owner of the Hobgoblin in Bishopston, Bristol, delivered a scathing response to a review of the pubShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Hobgoblin pub in Bishopston, Bristol"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA customer who left a one-star TripAdvisor review of a pub was given short shrt by the landlord in a blistering response. The customer had allegedly claimed she was a police officer and that her human rights were violated when staff refused to give her a free round of drinks when she dropped the previous round on the floor. She later took to TripAdvisor to claim that the pubs staff had taken a disliking to her group and had an issue with happy people, Bristol Live reports.In his scathing riposte, landlord James Aylfe asked the woman, Hows the head this morning , and claimed she had been kicked out of the Hobgoblin pub in Bristol. His reply is serving as another example of bar and restaurant owners hitting back at bad reviews.   The woman, registered on TripAdvisor as ‘Chloe A’ posted on the public review website on Saturday night after allegedly being kicked out of the venue.Her review was headed ‘unreasonable’, and complained the bar staff took her for being drunk, even though she said she wasn’t. She explained how she and four friends had entered the pub but her stay did not last long. “The staff took a disliking to us the second we walked in,” she wrote. “We are a group of five who haven’t seen each other since uni. “They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishment. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people,” she added. At least that is the best interpretation of what Chloe A wrote on TripAdvisor, Bristol Live reported.She actually tapped in: “The staff good a disliking to use the second we walked in. We are a group of  who haven’t seen us since uni. They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishmst. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people.” Hobgoblin owner James saw the review the next day, and claims he immediately recognised who Chloe A was from the night before. He decided to respond to set the record straight, and also back up his staff, who were allegedly left upset by the experience of dealing with Chloe.   James response on TripAdvisor began inquiring after her health, before saying she might not be able to remember exactly what happened. He explained things began well - she was served a round of drinks with no problem. But then Chloe A’s time in the Hobgoblin took something of a downward turn almost immediately, because as she carried them back to the table, she spilt all the drinks after ‘stumbling away from the bar, barging into another customer’ And it was at this point, according to James, it started getting a little weird, and rather unpleasant for the staff behind the bar. She ed to the bar and ‘aggressively demanded’ replacement drinks for free, James wrote. “At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff,” he wrote, followed up by a scathing remark. “You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . “You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights,” he added. But James went on to explain the effect this behaviour had on staff and other customers. One member of staff was reduced to tears, other customers complained about her behaviour, he said. And when the assistant manager asked Chloe A to leave, she was not going to go quietly. According to James, she ‘continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights’. “So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person,” he added, before ending by stating he was ‘completely comfortable’ with how she was treated by his staff, and suggesting that she should perhaps come to the bar with an apology. Since he posted the response on the pubs Facebook page, it has gone viral. Bristol Live has messaged Chloe A, but is yet to receive a response. James said he took the decision to share his response as a show of support for the staff involved. We dont get many one-star reviews, in fact I think hers was the just the third, so mercully we havent particularly suffered from reviews like this, he told Bristol Live . I didnt want to make a big deal about it, but I didnt feel I could just leave it unanswered. What has been really nice is that the response from customers has been almost universally positive - its been really nice to see, and nice for the staff, becauseyou get a slightly unpleasant experience it can knock your confidence in dealing with people. What was also good was that a number of people commented that they were there and that the staff did really well and acted properly, he added. James Aylfes response in full Hi Chloe, Hows the head this morning  Id be surprisedyou can actually remember your behaviour last night so, just in case its a little foggy, lets have a recap, shall we  Although you were initially served a round of drinks, after you stumbled away from the bar and barged into another customer, dropping your drinks on the floor, we began to realise that you werent *entirely* sober. This assessment was further strengthened when you ed to the bar, aggressively demanding that your spilt drinks be replaced for free. You were refused. At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff. You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights. In the cold light of this morning these were rather obviously the angry ravings of someone well in their cups but as funny as it sounds now, you were extremely aggressive and intimidating at the time. A number of other customers commented that your behaviour was inappropriate, and you reduced the member of bar staff to tears. Once we had discussed what had happened, we decided that frankly it would be bestyou all moved on and we informed you that we wouldnt be serving you any further. Instead of leaving quietly with your friends you continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights. So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person. Im really not sure that paints you in a particularly flattering light either way and I am completely comfortable with how you were dealt with last night. As for where we go from here, Ill leave that up to you. title: touching way prince philip told
story: NewsTouching way Prince Philip told Queen her le had changed forever following dads deathKing George VI died on February , , and his eldest daughter succeeded him to the throneShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB NewsPrince Philip and the then Princess Elizabeth on their trip to Kenya "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn February , , the Queens le changed forever. Her beloved father, King George VI passed away in his sleep and she became the Queen. When the news was broken to Princess Elizabeth she was enjoying a holiday in Kenya with her husband, Prince Philip. The evening before, she had been taking pictures of the incredible wildle from their tree top hideaway, including baboons, elephants and even a warthog. The princess had even asked to eat her evening meal outside in the Treetops hotel so she could continue to take photographs into the night.   And she had even woke early the next day to capture two rhinos fighting at a watering hole nearby. The couple got ready to depart for the next stage of their tour, which should have also taken them to New Zealand and Australia. But first they were travelling to a fishing lodge called Sangana some  miles away. Back in England, at Sandringham, the Kings staff were preparing to wake him for the day. Despite his recent bout of ill health, he had been happy the previous day and had even been on a shoot with a friend.   His final acts were to play with his two grandchildren, Charles and Anne, and have dinner with his youngest daughter, Princess Margaret. James McDonald, the Kings valet, realised something was seriously wrong with the monarch when he ran him a bath and he didnt wake as he usually did. A doctor was called to the palace who confirmed the sad news that King George had passed away in his sleep. But the couples secluded and isolated location meant it was almost impossible to break the terrible news to the princess that her father was dead. Journalist Granville Roberts, who was covering the royal tour, was the first person to receive the news in Kenya.  After it had been announced the country, Roberts spotted a breaking news memo from Reuters confirming that the king was dead. He immediately told Prince Philips private secretary, Commander Michael Parker, who tuned into the BBC to confirm the news. The Duke of Edinburgh had been taking an afternoon nap and was stunned when he was woken told the sad news. And Prince Philip now had to work out how he would tell his we the tragic news that the father she adored had died and she was now Queen. Rather than tell his we in a formal setting, surrounded by their staff, Philip took her for a walk in the grounds of the lodge they were staying in.  It was a private moment for the couple while Elizabeth could be alone with her husband during her moment of grief. She was just -years-old. Ever aware of her public duty, Elizabeth immediately discussed the practicalities of herto England. But she also asked for an hour alone in her room. The Queenswas delayed for several hours due to a storm. Her staff also realised her mourning outfit had already been sent on by plane to the next stop on her royal tour.  When the royal plane touched down in London, a black dress was brought on board for her to change into before she emerged to the full glare of the press and public. Prime Minsiter Winston Churchill was in the welcome party to greet Britains new queen home. Her coronation took place the following year and the first ever to be televised. Queen Elizabeth II is now the longest-reigning monarch and became the first British monarch to celebrate her Sapphire Jubilee -  years on the throne - last year.

story: NewsWoman unrecognisable after ditching £-a-day takeaway habit and losing  STONEAlysha McNair, , from Canada, weighed more than  stone at her heaviest after her eating habits spiralled completely out of controlShareCommentsByCharlotte Nisbet:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video woman-shows-dramatic--stone-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman looks unrecognisable after dropping  stone by ditching her pound-per-day fast food addiction. But Alysha, from British Columbia, Canada, decided to change her ways after realising she had just two options - change or die. I had even dropped out of school at  as I was bullied so bad that I no longer believed I was beautul and was never invited out to do things with kids my age. title: dundee and angus college lecturers back on strike
story: College lecturers in Dundee and Arbroath yesterday held a second period of industrial action in a dispute over pay.Teaching staff at all three Dundee and Angus College campuses are on strike for the second time in the space of a month.The action follows a walk-out on January , organised by the EIS and FELA unions.All classes have been cancelled, however libraries and study areas have been opened to allow for student access.Lecturers and staff claim Colleges Scotland has constantly “misled” the negotiation process by adding the salaries and the cost of living claim together.John Gribben, of Colleges Scotland Employers’ Association, said: “We have met with the EIS-FELA on  occasions to discuss pay and will be meeting them again on Thursday to try to end this disruptive strike action.“The EIS-FELA is aware that colleges are already having to make cuts to finance the additional pay offer which they have rejected. Their unreasonable pay demands would mean fewer courses, fewer students, and fewer lecturing jobs in the college sector.”

title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: ewan gurr a rising number of people are committing to the church cause
story: It has become common to read of declining numbers at church congregations but a recent YouGov survey appeared to suggest, to the contrary, that there has been a drop in the number who self-identy as atheists. vw, px"  Among , respondents, the number saying they had no belief dropped from  to %, while church attendance increased by %.Commenting on the figures, religious affairs correspondent, Kaya Burgess, recently wrote: “It has long been assumed that the decline in weekly congregations is down to Britons losing their religion and abandoning the church.”However, he goes on to state his belief that the survey appears to suggest that more people are attending church less frequently rather than giving up on belief itself.Jim Turrent, lead pastor of Central Baptist Church in Dundee, which has a thriving student body and an average of  weekly attendees, believes that inidualism, consumerism and a decrease in brand loyalty has contributed to decreases in regular church attendance.However, he adds: “There is a rising generation, however, that are more committed to the cause than the institution and that is, to some extent, a positive.”

title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call to kick Inverness free parking to the kerb
story: A DRIVE to extend free parking in Inverness city centre has been described by regional Green MSP John Finnie as short-sighted and a danger to public health.City businesses would like to see the scheme which allows drivers to park for free for  minutes to be extended to half-an-hour.And they are being backed by city councillor and depute Inverness Provost Bet McAllister.The scheme was introduced last year following a campaign by the Inverness Courier and Inverness Business Improvement District and its up for review this month.Local traders said they would like to see the time limit extended so they can conduct more business.It was introduced to help improve the footfall in shops in the city centre which have been adversely affected by out-of-town retail parks.But Mr Finnie has opposed the scheme from the outset.He said the plans are ldquoshort-sighted, ill-informed and a danger to public health pointing out the city centre is already one of Scotlandrsquos air pollution hot spots.Mr Finnie said: ldquoAir pollution is the cause in thousands of deaths each year, and exacerbates many serious medical conditions.ldquoPlans to extend free parking in the city centre are ill-informed and increase the risk of air pollution related illness and death.ldquoWe need to encourage people to leave their cars at home and use buses or walk and cycle in and around Inverness. Increasing the number of cars in the city simply frustrates these efforts. More congestion means buses are less likely to run on time, for instance.He added: ldquoResearch shows that investing in cycling can signicantly improve shop occupancy and town centre spend. The Highland Council should focus its energies on putting in place quality segregated cycle routes, pedestrian prioritisation, and improving bus services, rather than inviting more and more cars into town.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Intake cap at seven Inverness schools
story: SEVEN Inverness schools will have their rolls capped in - academic session.The move was triggered by high demand for places at each school.The primary schools affected by the cap are Holm, Lochardil, Kinmylies and Milton of Leys while three secondary schools ndash Charleston, Culloden and Millburn Academies ndash will also have the first year intake limited.The local authority said it will do its best to accommodate all pupils in their preferred choice of school but warned that they would be subject to criteria.Pupils must be within the Highland area and within the geographical catchment of the school concerned or  certied medical reasons or additional support needs best be served by a specic school are needed.If pupils had siblings at a particular school that would also help their case while religious belief for denominational schools would also be a factor.Educational courses unavailable at one school or pupils living within the catchment area of a secondary school that is not subject to capping might impact where a child can go as would proximity to home to school and road safety or ease of travel.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: New mascot design sees Inverness pupil in a league of his own
story: A NEW football mascot is set to cheer on teams playing in the Scottish Womenrsquos Premier League after being designed by a talented Inverness youth.Crown Primary School pupil Finlay Hamiltoncombined his love of the West Highland terriers his grandparents used to have along with his own interest in the bagpipes ndash which he is now learning to play ndash to create the mascot for league sponsor the Scottish Building Society.His design triumphed in a national competition run by the building society for children aged eight to  years old and Finlay is now looking forward to seeing his idea become a reality.Finlayrsquos dad, Andy Hamilton, said: ldquoHe was over the moon when I told him he had won.ldquoHe simply could not believe it and I had to show him the email before it started to sink in.ldquoHe canrsquot wait until his design is brought to le.Head of marketing and communications for the Scottish Building Society, Kerra McKinnie, said: ldquoFinlayrsquos drawing of the West Highland Terrier really drew our attention and we look forward to seeing his creation cheering on the players at Scottish Womenrsquos Premier League football matches across the country.She added that the idea for the competition formed part of th anniversary celebrations for the building society, with the mascot also to be used to promote its own activities.Lesley Devine, the building societyrsquos Inverness branch manager, also offered her congratulations to young Finlay.ldquoAfter announcing the competition before Christmas, we are delighted that after a long search up and down Scotland, the winner has been selected here in Inverness, she said.ldquoWe canrsquot wait to see Finlayrsquos drawing come to le!Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: call to register interest in child adoption in north east
story: A leading north-east councillor has urged people who are considering adopting a child to register their interest.Aberdeenshire Council’s adoption team is offering assistance and support to families who are interested in joining the programme.The local authority offers a full in-house permanence planning service for children to allow them to move in with families who have worked with adoption services and have been properly prepared for the process.Bosses at the service say this allows them to tailor support accordingly for both the families and the children in their care.Concurrency planning is offered where the children are under two years old, along with post-adoption care.In its most recent Care Inspectorate report, the service received the top rating for its staffing and quality of care and support.Councillor Gillian Owen, chairwoman of the council’s education and children’s services committee, said: “There are children in Aberdeenshire who desperately need families, soyou are considering adoption, I would encourage you to register for the preparation to adopt course to seeit is for you.”“The team are friendly, supportive and have a wealth of knowledge about the process of adoption.“They take great care in matching children with families as well as using techniques and strategies to help children and their new family bond together in a loving and caring environment.”

title: former aberdeen nightclub up for sale
story: A former nightclub and bar in the heart of Aberdeen has been put up for sale.The building at - Windmill Brae, which formerly housed The Garage, Steinhaus and Traffic, is available in part or as a whole.The premises licence remains in place for the ,sqft property, located within walking distance of Union Street and the railway station.It contains several bar areas across three floors.It is being marketed by Shepherd Chartered Surveyors and DM Hall, acting as joint agents.Shepherd Chartered Surveyors associate James Morrison said: “Given its location within a well-established city centre leisure area and the fact it is available in part or whole, we anticipate keen interest in this opportunity.”Offers over £, are being invited for the premises, which is also available for lease.

title: new food initiative could be served up across aberdeen
story: Bosses of an innovative new food initiative hope it can eventually expand across Aberdeen.The Woodside Pantry, due to open to the public next Monday, offers a new way for people in financial trouble to get food.Led by Community Food Initiatives North East , the pantry offers an innovative subscription service to members and is the first of its kind to exist in Scotland.An annual subscription fee of £ and a £. supplement before every visit entitles members to take  items of their choice, including up to three exclusive items.Dave Simmers, the CEO of CFINE, hopes that –the scheme is successful – it can be rolled out to other regeneration areas across the city.Plans have also been hatched to create a pantry and clothes shop at the charity’s Poynenook Road headquarters.Mr Simmers said: “The Woodside Pantry is the first in Scotland, but we’re speaking with the Scottish Government and with Aberdeen City Council about investment to firstly establish a pantry at our premises, along with a clothes store.“Then what we want to do is to establish a network of community pantries across the city’s regeneration areas.”Mr Simmers said: “One of the most unfortunate parts of the past seven years has been the rise in foodbank use.“Our foodbank is up to more than  parcels daily, Monday to Friday. There’s a general agreement that it’s not very dignied.“The pantry is a way for people to access affordable food, but they’re paying for it.”Claire Whyte is a support worker at Fersands and Fountain Community Project, and also a partner in the pantry with CFINE.She said: “CFINE approached us with the concept, which is designed to replace foodbanks. We had a shop and a foodbank, and no one was really using the shop, but the foodbank was inundated.“It was the same at CFINE when they approached us, so I think it was just perfect timing.”Claire agreed with Mr Simmers that the pantry model is one that could spread beyond the boundaries of Woodside.She said: “CFINE want to roll several of these out across the city, so we’re really just the guinea pigs here.“They’re hoping to reach into every regeneration area, or at least most of them, in the city over the next few years.“This is just the start of something that is going to be much bigger in Aberdeen and hopefully across the country once we get this set up.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. story: NewsBob Shields: National Trust owe an apology over asking people for donations to restore Burns CottageShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBurns Cottage needs restoration"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m trying to imagine the back-slapping and glad-handing at the National Trust For Scotland’s Hermiston Quay headquarters when someone came up with a spfing ‘Save Burns Cottage’ wheeze. “Let’s send out a begging letter to all those with Burns Cottage closest to their hearts – the people of Ayr . . .” “Wonderful idea!” “We could arrange for it to land on their doorsteps on Burns birthday – January  . . .” “That’s genius!” “Throw in some pictures of cracked walls and the dodgy thatched roof . . . “ “Fantastic!” “Use phrases like “before it’s too late” – or “damaged beyond repair” . . . “It’s heartbreaking!” “That’s Burns Cottage sorted then! Gin and tonic anyone ” “Large ones all round!” To be serious though – I still can’t decide what made me angrier. The crass begging bowl letter – hoping to cash in on the biggest Burns day of the year  Or the fact that Burns Cottage has been allowed to fall into such a state that phrases like “damaged beyond repair” are even necessary  If we’re talking man’s insensitivity to man here – then last Friday’s NTS letter takes the bannock! Its contents have upset dozens of people I know – and judging by the reaction on social media, hundreds more that I don’t know. Nicky Cotter wrote: “NTS . . . put your hands in your pockets and get it fixed. If you can spend pound, on a wooden tree house at Culzean Castle – you can stump up pound, to fix one of the most historically and culturally signicant buildings in Scotland”. Spot on, sir. The NTS letter tells us that “time and Scotland’s wet winters have taken their toll”. Yes – that’ll be the  winters since Burns father William Burness built the cottage on . And during that period, it’s been thatched more times than Wayne Rooney’s balding napper. If the current thatch “has signicant tears and has worn away”, you have to askthe last thatching work was in some way inferior - orthe cottage needed re-thatched several years ago and the work was never undertaken  You then start wondering how the auld clay biggin’ managed to survive the  wet Scottish winters between the cottage being built and the National Trust for Scotland’s formation back in   The answer is fairly obvious. Back then – people looked after it! And you only have to look at the recent row over the deteriorating Burns Monument to start wonderingthe NTS is the right custodian of our Burns heritage  Burns Cottage is everything Mr Cotter said earlier . .. and more. It’s the most important building in Ayrshire – by a lang Scots mile. Every nook, cranny - and twig of its roof - should be the subject of a fingertip, annual inspection. And whatever work is required – at whatever cost – should be sanctioned immediately. In fact, I imagine that’s what ‘most people’ thought was already happening. But then we had last Friday’s mail . . . when ‘most people’ discovered to their horror that the north-west gable is starting to pull away from the rest of the cottage! If admission fees don’t cover the cost of Burns Cottage – then put them up! The last figures I have show , visitors in . Charging them an extra p would have reached the pound, required – with enough left over to putty the windows as well. So, I’m sorry, NTS. But this was the wrong letter . . . to the wrong people . . . on the wrong day. You owe a lot of honest men and a lot of bonnie lassies an apology!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

story: NewsFormer Royal Hotel in Ayr is sold at auctionBuilding is branded the most dangerous in the townShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB NewsRoyal Hotel Ayr"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe former Royal Hotel, which has been described as the most dangerous building in Ayr, has been sold at auction. The three and a half storey building, which has lain empty for more than  years, consists of two commercial shop units on the ground floor and sandstone units above is located on Kyle Street. A spokesman for Wilsons Auctions Land  Property Sales, said: “Unfortunately we cannot disclose any further detail on this property in terms of the identity of the purchaser or the sale price . “However this figure will be disclosed by the Registers of Scotland and the Ei Group in the coming months.” In May, the Post reported how plans to knock it down and turn it into a gym were rejected by councillors. title: pet heaven crematorium opens doors
story: NewsPet Heaven crematorium opens doors in Ayr as businessman offers new serviceBusinessman Forbes Robertson is bidding to provide a new service for animal owners in South Ayrshire.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsForbes at the helm of his newest business "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen an adored pet pops off its mortal coil you used to allow the vet to handle it, or a space was found in the back garden. Now the proposition has got a whole lot dferent. Pet Heaven, a crematorium for family animals, has just opened in Ayr. And businessman Forbes Robertson believes it is the answer for many families who want to give their four legged - or two-legged in the case of birds - friends a splendid send-off. No expense has been spared in an -month project at the former commercial garage site in West Sanquhar Road. Area MP Bill Grant performed the official opening ceremony last week. The lavishly decorated gilded interior includes a parlour where families can pay their last respects. Entrepreneur Forbes, who has business interests throughout the area, revealed up to  people can attend the pet funeral services . Mourners can watch as their pet recedes behind the final curtain at the close of the service, similar to what would happen in a human ceremony at Masonhill. As yet Pet Heaven cannot handle horses, but the biggest of dogs to cats, hamsters and birds. There is a tea and coffee service as well as any choice of music desired and a book of remembrance in the reception area.  Much of the interior decoration has been gathered by Forbes, a keen antique hunter and auction room collector. The company will offer a collection service as well as provide a selection of remembrance urns for ashes. It seems no expense is spared by some dog lovers in the UK and recently a couple spent pound on a full funeral including a horse drawn glass hearse. Forbes said: “People sometimes care more about their animals than humans. “A farmer who contacted me askedhis dog goes before him, the animal would be cremated here and I will store the ashes. “He told me his lawyer would be in touch as he wanted buried with his dog. “Pets are loyal, they don’t steal from you and are there first thing in the morning and last thing at night.” MP Bill Grant said Pet Heaven was a signicant investment for the area. He said: “I am sure this will be welcomed by pet owners from all over the southwest, pet owners who have lost their best friend. “To have a dignied departure for that pet who has been their friend - in some cases for  years - is a great service. “The set-up Mr Robertson has here is wonderful and I think he can be proud of it. “That last journey for pets will be full of dignity and respect from Pet Heaven and its staff. “Indeed my family had a wee dog Blackie for  years and I don’t mind admitting, then a senior fire officer, that I cried unashamedly for an hour at the loss of our companion”.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPetsSanquharAyr News

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Chilly winter mornings lead usto spend an extra  hoursin bed over the colder months - just from hitting the snooze button.Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: confused-commuters-have-world-turned-upside-down-in-galashiels
story: COMMUTERS had their world turned upside down in Galashiels last week.For four or five days confused bus passengers at the Transport Interchange struggled to read the real-time arrival and departure screens - as they were all upside down.And the confusion continued right through to the start of this week.Selkirk pensioner Jaye Riddell told us: "It was a bit dficult to make out when buses were due - I cant read upside down writing."There was one child lying on the ground trying to read the times out to to his grandparents."Thankfully the train timetables were the right way up."Scottish Borders Council is responsible for the large interactive timetable screens at the Transport Interchange.And their IT people managed to fix the upside-down problem on Monday.A spokesman told us: "The issue with the information boards has been resolved and everything is the right way up now."

title: ben-magowan-announced-as-melrosian-elect-for-2019
story: TAKING up the reins as this years Melrosian-Elect is a -year-old childrens nurse from Gattonside.Ben Magowan was announced in the role at the annual Ex-Melrosians Association Burns Supper on Saturday night.The former pupil of Melrose Primary, St Marys School and Earlston High said: "I was very nervous on the evening but its such an honour to be asked to be the Melrosian-Elect."It was an exciting evening and I had my family there to support me."Im already looking forward to the summer and have started learning about the other towns festivals."The Burns Supper was a sell-out and guests were entertained by Sandy Telfer who proposed the toast to the Immortal Memory followed by Harry Fletchers Toast to the Lassies and Annabel Crawfords reply.
