title: letters-remainers-should-not-give-up-and-should-become-returners
story: Lying being not only acceptable but effective, the Brexiters cannot give up their compulsion. For instance consider the Conservative MP Daniel Kawczynskirsquos distortion of the truth regarding our share of Marshall Plan aid .However, much more serious is the fact that Mrs May is either distorting our unwritten constitution or is seeking to ldquorewrite it to meet the needs of her eternally discredited party. She claimed last week that she opposed the Grieve and Cooper amendments on the grounds that they ldquowould allow Parliament to usurp the proper role of the Executive. This is utter nonsense. I understand that ldquo there is any democratic legitimacy in our system, it lies with the democratically elected MPs. As Edmund Burke said ldquoYour representative owes you ... his judgment and he betrays, instead of serving you,he sacrices it to your opinionhellip"How should we Remainers react to the looming catastrophe  I suggest that we do so by refusing to give up and by becoming Returners. As Will Hutton has said, ldquothe British are culturally and philosophically Europeans the consequence being that many of the  million who voted Remain will surely have no intention of giving up that heritage, ever.John Milne, Ardgowan Drive, Uddingston.AS we get closer to the clf edge of a No Deal Brexit, we have to ponder the possible predicament of the UK.Despite the optimistic noises of the May contingent, rather like whistling in the dark, that the EU will relent and offer changes to the Withdrawal Agreement, we could well see ourselves out in the cold from March .It is all rather reminiscent of the Prodigal Son, a story where a young man, guaranteed an inheritance, decided he wanted independence to make his own way in the world.Many of us know how that ended. He squandered his opportunities, fell into hard times and came back chastened to his father who forgave him his errors and welcomed him home.Could the same fate await the UK, which demands sovereignty and striking out on its own I doubt that the EU will be as charitable and forgiving as the father of the prodigal sonwe fall on hard times and come back chastened, seeking our former relationship with the EU.Denis Bruce, Rannoch Gardens, Bishopbriggs.ITS increasingly clear there wont be a second EU referendum, plus, while Article  may be delayed, it wont be revoked. So its Theresa Maysdeal or No Deal ndash thats the most likely binary choice available to our  MPs. Nicola Sturgeon opposes Theresa Mays compromise deal while absolutely insisting no deal is the very worst outcome for Scotland ndash so how are her  SNP MPs going to vote in the Commons  Alongside Jacob Rees-Moggs ardent Brexiters for the probable chaos of No Deal ndash or, albeit reluctantly, for Theresa Mays compromise  Both are politically untenable to the SNP. But is Ms Sturgeon capable of putting aside her Scotland versus the rest of the UK games and puerile party-political point-scoring, to do whats best for the people of Scotland Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.CHRISTOPHER Idesays there are ious reasons people voted Leave but the fact is Brexiters rubbished the benefits of EU membership and called well-informed warnings "Project Fear". Yet our membership was central to the Thatcher sales pitch which led to the opening of Nissanrsquos Sunderland car plant.Even on Sunday, when Nissan itself explained that Brexit was a factor in its decision to build the new SUV in Japan, airtime was still given to Jacob Rees-Mogg to deny this though he has no car industry expertise or experience and his Somerset constituency could hardly be further away from the north-east.As an ordinary minister, Theresa May admitted a great deal of inward investment depended on us being part of the EU. Sadly, as Prime Minister she tried to hide her own Governmentrsquos assessments of the economic damage Brexit would do ndash especially to the north-east of England ndash ploughing on asthe  vote was sacred.Rev Dr John Cameron, Howard Place, St Andrews.AT the weekend I was watching The Italian Joband I was struck by the last scene and how it was very like the current Brexit situation. There you had Michael Caine inching towards the gold bars and the bus precariously balanced on the clf edge, telling his gang of English football supporters to move back to counter balance his weight and telling them that no-one should try to get off the bus. As the balance shts and the gold slides further away to the end of the coach Cane turns to his companions and say "wait a minute lads, Ive got an idea".And the scene shts to the outside and the soundtrack comes up with the theme song We are The Self Preservation Society, whichJacob Rees-Mogg, David Cameron et al had been on the coach is highly appropriate.It found it amusing and quite apposite regarding the position we are in. The fact the characters in the film heist are all English and all the foreign chaps are either evil or incompetent or both sounds like Boris et al speaking about those EU coves trying to do down the crooks. All that was missing was Caine in leopard-print kitten heels and we would be in Brussels.Ronald H Oliver, Woodside Road, Elie.Read more:IM truly at a loss at trying to understand our friends and neighbours, the Irish.One hundred years ago they demanded "their right" to be an independent sovereign nation making its own laws and economic decisions.Is it not somewhat ironical and somewhat galling when Great Britain has voted to take back its right to make its laws and economic decisions again, we now have a situation where the Irish Taoiseach and his unelected EU friends in Brussels are endeavouring to obstruct Britains democratic decision to do so.Ironic, nest pas mes amis Robin Gilmour,Mosspark Avenue, Glasgow.MUCH is being made of the sense of loyalty between Ireland and the EU and now with the United States. However, the loyalty shown by the UK to Ireland in making a pound billion contribution towards helping it during the financial crisis despite the UKs own problems seems to have been quickly forgotten.Paul Lewis, Guardwell Crescent, Edinburgh.Read more: PM must abort Brexit kamikaze mission

title: bins to be collected once every three weeks in new council strategy
story: Aberdeenshire residents will be encouraged to become recycling champions with the introduction of a controversial three-weekly collection programme.The revised waste strategy for all , properties in the Shire was approved in a - vote by the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee despite an alternative option from Peterhead SNP councillor Stephen Smith who said it was “too much, too soon”.From April next year, households will have weekly kerbside collections for one of three bins including a  litre bin for paper and card and  litre bin for metals, plastics and cartons.However under the new scheme, the existing general residual bin for non-recyclable waste will be signicantly reduced to a  litre capacity.Councillors were told by waste director Philip McKay that while it was a considerable reduction, the service felt it “should be manageable for most households”.He added that while a three-weekly non-recyclable waste collection might feel a bit daunting to residents initially – as did the move from weekly to fortnightly collections in Aberdeenshire a few years ago – experience from other Scottish local authorities showed that it is workable and can lead to a signicant increase in recycling rates.Mr McKay also stressed that given the larger recycling capacity provided in the favoured option, it provided “more flexibility in the future” for the addition of other recyclable materials without the need for additional recycling containers.Councillors were told that the scheme had the potential to save waste services £, per year at the lower end of the scale and even morethere was a higher uptake in recycling.However, Peterhead councillor Stephen Smith said the proposals as they stood were a step too far for North-east communities.In a bid to address concerns about the potential impact of any necessary changes to the waste strategy, he proposed that instead of using a -litre bin for three weekly collections, Aberdeenshire Council instead do what has happened in much of the rest of Scotland and keep the  litre bin for three weekly waste collections, with new  litre bins – which are expected to be funded in large part by ‘Zero Waste Scotland’ – being used for paper and card recycling for a transitional period.Councillor Smith’s proposal – which he claimed would have saved an estimated £, annually – followed confirmation from council officers that such a proposal would be compatible with Zero Waste Scotland’s requirements for helping to fund the cost of the new bins required.But council depute leader Peter Argyle warned against “changing horses” halfway through the programme as it would only lead to confusion.He told the committee that with an imminent landfill ban on biodegradable waste “coming down the tracks” by , it was “unacceptablewe don’t recycle” and questioned how people would be encouraged to recycle morethey continued to have the larger residual waste bin.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch title: posting parcels to eu countries after brexit
story: Q: I have an online business with  per cent international sales, but neither Royal Mail nor the Post Office can sayCN customs labels are going to be required for the EEA EU.Any idea A CN is a customs document, used when goods are being transported overseas. It contains a description and value of the item being posted along with the country of origin. It is valid for items up to £, while a CN label is the same, but for goods worth £ and over.Electronic customs data needs to be supplied whenever a parcel is required to go through Customs clearance. Currently this is applicable to only countries outside of the EU.However, Royal Mails official advice to customers is that they DO prepare to send data to all countries following Brexit.Readers questions: Will I need a new passport after Brexit As you will know, at the minute theres no need for customs declarations or clearance on anything you post to EU destinations. If we leave with a withdrawal agreement it is likely that nothing will change, at least during the transition period until .Butthere is a no-deal Brexit then the current guidance from HMRC is that the same rules will apply to UK businesses exporting to the EU as do to non-EU countries from March .This means that your goods will require a CN or CN form.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The CE safety symbol belongs to the EU"  UK plans new safety certicate mark for when we leave EU viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MILN | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MILN | Article Teaser"

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: uk plans new safety certificate mark for when we leave eu
story: The current CE symbol, which shows consumers that an item meets legal requirements, belongs to the EU.To prepare for a no-deal scenario, the UK government has drawn up a new logo, called the UKCA - UK Conformity Assessed.This is the marking that will be used, subject to parliamentary approval, for certain goods being placed on the UK market.In many cases, firms will still be able to use the CE marking to demonstrate compliance with the legal requirements, but in some cases they will need to apply the new UKCA marking to products being sold in the UK.To check whether your business will need to use the UKCA marking, click here.The rules for using the new UK conformity marking will be the same as those now used for CE marking.Read more: Five top tips to Brexit proof your holidaydata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fetoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  £, floor laid as Fe leisure centre re-opens viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"

title: what is the future for erasmus students after brexit
story: Irsquom supposed to be here until the end of May. However,the UK parliament canrsquot negotiate with the EU, what is going to happen  Will I have to leave A. The message is clear: you are our friends, our neighbours, our colleagues, and we want you to stay.EU citizens and their family members who are resident in the UK by March  will be able to stay and carry on with their lives in the same way they are now. They will be able to work, study, and access benefits and services in the UK on the same basis after we exit the EU as they do now.So, regardless of a deal or no deal, you will be allowed to study in Scotland - or other parts of the UK - for the rest of the semester.Read more: UK plans new safety certicate mark for when we leave EUWith regards to Erasmus+ funding, the UK will remain in the programme until at least a deal is agreed. title: wine drinkers could be seeing red over brexit price rises
story: The Journal of Wine Economics featured an industry study that says that the amount customers pay could increase by up to  per cent by  in the event of a hard Brexit, or  per cent in terms of a softer Brexit.British vineyards could benefit however.According to a report by WSTA, the Wine and Spirit Trade Association,  percent of wine drunk in the UK is imported. Of this half is produced in the EU, while the remainder comes from Australia, USA, Chile, Argentina, South Africa and New Zealand. There are concerns thatthe right measures are not put in place it could stop imports from crossing the border, which has lead some retailers to stock up on bottles in advance.The WSTA has been advising members for more than a year that they should increase their stock by  per cent as a starting point in case of a no deal Brexit.Miles Beale, chief executive of the Wine and Spirit Trade Association, said: ldquoSince the Referendum, the WSTA has campaigned consistently for a deal with the EU that delivers frictionless trade in goods, with no additional tarfs or costs.ldquoIf the UK ends up with a no-deal Brexit then wine businesses will have to cope with additional tarfs as well as another duty rise - which is highly likely to end up full square in the consumerrsquos lap, bumping up wine prices to an all-time high.ldquoCurrently there are no tarfs on wines from the EU, Chile and South Africa. A no deal Brexit would result in the introduction of tarfs, estimated to cost UK wine importing businesses over £ million a year.ldquoThe introduction of no deal Brexit tarfs would be a double blow for wine businesses after the Chancellor elected to single out wine for a duty rise at the Autumn Budget.From February  the duty on a bottle of wine went up by p, but add a tarf to the duty rise and VAT and this means an average priced bottle of wine, which today costs £., will cost £. in the event of no deal.Read more: How will Brexit affect your travel plans  This is an extra p a bottle more than consumers paid before the referendum result when an average priced bottle of wine was £..There could be some positive benefits for British vineyards however.It is believed that British wines will seem less expensive than its European counterparts as retailers wonrsquot be forced to hike prices because of rate or tarfs.There are more than  vineyards and about  wineries in England and Wales, many of these specialising in sparkling wines.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.glasgowsouthandeastwoodextra webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Princess Royal Maternity Hospital. The WSTA also wants confirmation that funding that was before provided by the EU will be picked up somewhere .Tamara Roberts, CEO at Ridgeview in East Sussex, said: ldquoAs we prepare for Brexit, it will be critical that the government does all it can to help English wine grow and that includes continued access to funding streams.ldquoComplete confidence in the quality of our wines has allowed us to expand production but so has access to funding streams, some of which derive from EU structural funds.At the moment, while the future is uncertain as to what will happen with Brexit come March , it may be worthwhile buying a bottle or two extra of your favourite European tipple. title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeWednesday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. story: Councillors held discussions today with the Scottish Government constitutional relations secretary Michael Russell MSP over the potential impact on Orkney of the Brexit process.Mr Russell, who is leading the Scottish Government’s Brexit preparations, accepted an invitation from Orkney Islands Council leader James Stockan to visit the county and meet with councillors and senior officials.Following the meeting Councillor Stockan described the talks as #an extremely useful engagement# with Mr Russell.He added: #Everybody got the chance to ask questions today, including some dficult questions, and we had answers that were really worthwhile in an Orkney context.#What we hope is that he will leave with, is a real flavour of the challenge, whatever happens, there will be for us in Orkney.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Wednesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. title: football fans lose weight eat less sugar under scheme
story: A project that aims to improve the health of male football fans at  European clubs has resulted in #signicant# improvements in participants# weight and diet, according to research.The European Fans in Trainingprogramme was also found to have led to improvements in the men’s sense of wellbeing and self-esteem.The EU-funded scheme involved more than , men between the ages of  and  who are fans of football clubs in England, the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal.Arsenal, Manchester City, PSV Eindhoven, Rosenborg and FC Porto were among the clubs involved in the programme, which was based on a model developed in Scotland.During the EuroFIT programme, fans attended weekly -minute sessions with community coaches at club facilities over  weeks. The aim was to increase their levels of physical activity and improve their diet.A pocket-worn device developed for the programme allowed monitoring of theof time spent sitting and the number of daily steps participants were doing, while an app encouraged social support between sessions.Participants were split into two groups – the first joining the EuroFIT programme immediately and the second being placed on a -month waiting list.After a year, men who took part in EuroFIT were doing on average  steps a day more than the comparison group.The men had also improved their diet by eating more fruit and vegetables, less fat and less sugar and had increased their wellbeing and vitality.Attempts to reduce theof time spent sitting were unsuccessful.The research papers found there were “signicant improvements in diet, weight, wellbeing, self-esteem, vitality, and biomarkers of cardiometabolic health in favour of the intervention group”, although not in their quality of le.EuroFIT was built on the experience of the Football Fans in Trainingprogramme for overweight and obese men, which was developed and evaluated by researchers led by the University of Glasgow.It is delivered in Scotland by the Scottish Professional Football League Trust and has been adapted for use in Canada and Australia.Professor Sally Wyke, the programme’s principal investigator, said: “The results of our randomised control trial of EuroFIT support the findings of the earlier FFIT study.“Gender-sensitised lestyle programmes delivered in professional football clubs show great promise in Europe and could play an important public health role in engaging under-served men.”The English clubs involved were Arsenal, Everton, Newcastle United, Manchester City and Stoke City.The other clubs across Europe taking part were ADO Den Haag, FC Groningen, PSV Eindhoven, Vitesse, Rosenborg, Stromsgodset, Valerenga, Benfica, FC Porto and Sporting CP.The European Healthy Stadia Network will be responsible for the rollout of EuroFIT across Europe.Matthew Philpott, the network’s executive director, said: “We are hugely excited about the rollout of EuroFIT as we now know this intervention is effective across dferent European countries.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: mary queen of scots fashion show to take place at edinburgh castle
story: On the eve of the anniversary of Mary, Queen of Scots# execution in , Jeff Garner and Historic Environment Scotland will pay tribute to her as the original royal fashion icon by unveiling their new collection on the catwalk. Taking inspiration from the Scottish monarch for the new spring summer line, the fashion show will be the first of its kind to take place in the Great Hall at Edinburgh Castle tomorrow. Born at Linlithgow Palace, Mary, Queen of Scots reigned over Scotland from  to . She spent much of her childhood at the royal court of France and ed to Scotland at the age of  to take her throne. Mary was a pillar of fashion in her day and clothes were important to her court. She used expensive clothing to visually display her rank and power. By wearing costly fabrics including velvet, satin and cloth of real gold and silver, she communicated to courtiers, ambassadors and the public that she had great financial resources at her command and that she was in the know about contemporary European fashions. As portrayed by Saoirse Ronan in the recent film, Mary Queen of Scots, she remains an icon of style and strength more than  years on.Historic Environment Scotland uncovered records of her fashion dolls and after presenting this research to Jeff Garner of design house Prophetik, the dolls became the main inspiration behind his collection. Further details of her extensive wardrobe which had been stored in Edinburgh Castle were revealed. It was filled with black satin gowns embellished with bands of other textured black fabrics and padded round shoulder pieces, commonly known as burlettis, which were highly fashionable in the s and s. However, Mary’s household was not dressed wholly in black. Gowns of silk ‘camelot’ were made for eight girls in her household, embellished with tanny velvet, a dull brownish purple colour which enjoyed a great deal of prestige in the th century, and double lined with taffeta.Prophetik designs which have been worn by everyone from Kings of Leon to Taylor Swt are often inspired by the dressmakers of the Civil War period who worked with what was in front of them, fashioning beautul gowns that were later taken apart to recreate new dresses – sustainability born out of necessity.Speaking about the show Jeff Garner says, “Women of the Crown defines a past when young kings had regents and strong queens ruled countries and inspired arts. Mary, Queen of Scots brought the beauty of fabrics to lighten the castles of Scotland.”The retail range produced by Historic Environment Scotland, in conjunction with Prophetik, is set to be showcased in the Queen Anne room during the catwalk show. The range features many of the fabrics and styles reminiscent of the th century, which grew in popularity thanks to Mary, Queen of Scots. The inventory, taken on  March  at the request of the Earl of Morton, who had resigned the regency, listed about  gowns – but more intriguingly, also included  or more fashion dolls known as poupines or ‘pippens’ in Scotland.A miniature bed and a horse-litterin the same group of objects belonging to Mary suggest that some of the dolls had been simply luxurious toys however. Due to their elaborate design, play may have been limited to the creation of tableaux rather than the recreation of domestic activities in doll’s houses. While dolls were traditionally considered as children’s playthings, with home-made rag dolls referred to in the th-century Scots poem Ratis Ravingused as puppets or as performing objects, by the second half of the th century, fashion dolls for privileged children were imported into England and Scotland. These were made of wood and papier mache and were presumably very expensive, commissioned primarily as fashion dolls for gting purposes. Carefully kept as luxurious and finely crafted objects, fashion dolls were intended as international courtly gts, from which garments were made up and worn, often as a compliment to a foreign court.Medieval and renaissance fashion dolls were sent between courts clothed in detailed miniature representations of current fashion, seemingly for reproducing the style of another court but perhaps exchanged in courtesy. A king might write for a doll to dress the ladies of his court, or a prospective bride might request a doll dressed in the fashion of her prospective husband’s court, just as in  Francis I requested a doll from the fashionable Isabella d’Este of Ferrara to dress the ladies of his court. She was known for her elegance and personal style and eagerly sought information on the dress of other courts. A fashion doll with a high degree of verisimilitude was more useful than a two-dimensional representation for exhibiting a new style of dress. Dolls could present a three-dimensional experience of fashionable garments, superior to drawings, paintings and prints. For this reason, the clothes were meticulously and accurately reproduced in a smaller scale, intended as an exemplar for others to copy.Adding to the diplomatic accounts and portraits, there is evidence that the dolls’ outfits would have been exquisitely crafted by tailors to display the new trends in materials, accessories and dress styles. In September , the leading court tailor Jacques de Seulis made grey and silver clothes for the dolls listed at Edinburgh Castle, permitting them to serve as mannequins showcasing female fashions. As well as an expression of style, the role of dolls could be extended into one of aides-memoire when they entered collections, serving to represent the manners and politics of other courts.The dolls are grouped in the inventory with items that may have formed the contents of Mary’s cabinet room including some exotic items such as the beak and feathers of rare birds, and her embroideries. A similar mix of objects can be found in the inventories of other women’s cabinets of this era: Catherine de Medici, Mary’s mother-in-law, also kept a group of dolls in armoires with luxury objects such as Eastern leather and Venetian masks, Chinese lacquers, antique medals, shell and coral, as did the family of Charles de Cossé Brissac, Marshall of France. These collections suggest that they were, or had become, curiosities held in the same kind of regard. Ultimately, the dolls were tokens of international affection, and were exchanged between powerful women across Renaissance Europe as a way of keeping abreast of the latest fashions. They were an expression of authority, imposing the queen’s style on the court and its followers and demonstrated the look of the day to the aristocratic women of higher rank who attended court as visitors and had their own tailors. This would result in women across Europe looking to Mary, for the latest fashion and trends.Natasha Troitino, head of retail for HES, says, “We are delighted to have this unique opportunity to work with an haute couture international designer to produce a capsule range of products inspired by Mary, Queen of Scots. The creation of Jeff Garner’s  collection, based on our historic sites and the story of Mary, Queen of Scots, has provided a  to showcase the rich abundance of creative industries Scotland has to offer, something which HES is passionate about. Along with the release of the film, Mary Queen of Scots, Scotland continues to be celebrated internationally and secure its place within modern culture.”The Women of the Crown catwalk show will be seen for the first time in the Great Hall of Edinburgh Castle tomorrow night, before it travels to London Fashion Week. The retail range will be available online at www.HistoricEnvironment.scot shop and at the Crown Shop in Edinburgh Castle. ©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: new bowel screening test proves a success in scotland with record numbers
story: The introduction of a simpler bowel screening test in Scotland has seen record numbers of people taking part. Scotland was the first part of the UK to introduce the Faecal Immunochemical Testin November . The new test requires the collection of just one sample, rather than three over a ten-day period as was previously the case.Statistics show that from November  to April ,  per cent of those eligible ed their FIT.In the same period the year before, uptake of the old test – the Faecal Occult Blood Test – was  per cent.The biggest improvement in participation with FIT has been amongst those living in the most deprived areas – up from  per cent to . per cent.The number of men doing the test also rose by more than nine percentage points, from . per cent to . per cent.There has been a marked increasein uptake amongst those who had never participated before, but previously had the opportunity to.Gordon Matheson, Cancer Research UK’s public affairs manager in Scotland, welcomed the fact the new testing kit had helped make it easier for people to take part in the bowel screening programme.He said: “Screening for bowel cancer saves lives because detecting cancer at an early stage increases the chances of successful treatment.“Scotland was the first UK nation to introduce this and the challenge for Scottish Government now is to address long-standing shortages among the staff who detect cancers, especially endoscopists and pathologists.“An ageing population means more people are being invited to screening, so NHS Scotland must recruit and retain enough key health professionalswe are to achieve the ambition of detecting and treating more cancers early.”In Scotland men and women aged  to  are invited every two years to take part in bowel screening.Healthcare Improvement Scotland has set a standard of  per cent for bowel screening participation.Public health minister Joe FitzPatrick said: “The fact that more people than ever before are taking part in the Scottish Bowel Screening Programme is very encouraging.“We know the earlier a cancer is detected, the greater the chances of successful treatment and often cure. This is why we launched our Detect Cancer Early programme in  backed by a £ million investment.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: new projects pay off as bp doubles up on profits
story: North Sea oil major BP has seen profits more than double to . billionfor , following higher oil prices and after it launched a raft of new projects.The energy giant’s underlying replacement cost profit – BP’s preferred income measure – surged from .bn in .The group’s fourth-quarter underlying earnings also jumped higher despite oil prices easing back at the end of last year, to .bn against .bn a year earlier.The FTSE  stalwart has been riding the wave of a rebound in the cost of crude in recent years, as has rival Royal Dutch Shell, which last week reported a  per cent jump in full-year profits. But BP has also been embarking on a number of new projects, which has been boosting production.Bob Dudley, group chief executive, said: “We now have a powerful track record of safe and reliable performance, efficient execution and capital discipline.“Our strategy is clearly working and will serve the company and our shareholders well through the energy transition.”The group’s annual figures were higher than expected for both the full year and the fourth quarter.On a reported basis, full-year profit rose to bn while fourth-quarter results showed it swinging to a .bn profit from a  million loss a year earlier.The firm said payments relating to the  Gulf of Mexico fatal oil spill tragedy stood at .bn in .BP recently announced plans to pump , more barrels of oil a day in the region, where it sparked one of the world’s biggest environmental disasters nearly nine years ago.Full-year results also showed it made estments of .bn of assets and the group announced plans to complete more than bn over the next two years.BP said it expects recent major projects to ramp up production in . It confirmed fourth-quarter shareholder idend payments of . cents a share, up . per cent on a year earlier.John Moore, senior investment manager at Brewin Dolphin, said: “Despite a volatile oil price at the tail end of last year, BP more than doubled profits in  as it showed cost, capital, and operational discipline across its businesses.“The company is aware of the changing energy landscape and is active in responding to that by going through signicant internal changes, in addition to external moves such as its deal to purchase BHP Billiton’s shale gas assets.“ may well be a year of further oil price volatility and additional industry change however, BP has shown a great deal of resilience and an ability to adapt to a rapidly changing energy landscape, which leaves it well placed.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
